law: Anything that can go wrong will go wrong.
Left to themselves, things tend to go from bad to worse.
Nothing is as easy as it looks.
Everything takes longer than you think.
If there is a possibility of several things going wrong, the one that will cause the most damage will be the one to go wrong.

corollary.law: If there is a worse time for something to go wrong, it will happen then.

law: If anything simply cannot go wrong, it will anyway.
If you perceive that there are four possible ways in which a procedure can go wrong, and circumvent these, then a fifth way, unprepared for, will promptly develop.
If everything seems to be going well, you have obviously overlooked something.
Whenever you set out to do something, something else must be done first.
Every solution breeds new problems.
Truck deliveries that normally take one day will take five when you are waiting for the truck.
After adding two weeks to the schedule for unexpected delays, add two more for the unexpected, unexpected delays.
In any structure, pick out the one piece that should not be mismarked and expect the plant to cross you up.

title: Murphy's Law of Research
law: Enough research will tend to support your theory.

title: Murphy's Law of Copiers
law: The legibility of a copy is inversely proportional to its importance.

title: Murphy's Law of the Open Road
law: When there is a very long road upon which there is a one-way bridge placed at random, and there are only two cars on that road, it follows that (1) the two cars are going in opposite directions, and (2) they will always meet at the bridge.

title: Murphy's Law of Thermodynamics
law: Things get worse under pressure.

title: Quantization Revision of Murphy's Laws
law: Everything goes wrong all at once.
Matter will be damaged in direct proportion to its value.
You can never tell which way the train went by looking at the track.
Logic is a systematic method of coming to the wrong conclusion with confidence.
Technology is dominated by those who manage what they do not understand.
An expert is one who knows more and more about less and less until he knows absolutely everything about nothing.
All great discoveries are made by mistake.
Nothing ever gets built on schedule or within budget.
A meeting is an event at which the minutes are kept and the hours are lost.
The first myth of management is that it exists.
A failure will not appear till a unit has passed final inspection.
New systems generate new problems.
To err is human, but to really foul things up requires a computer.
Any given program, when running, is obsolete.
Nothing motivates a man more than to see his boss putting in an honest day's work.
The primary function of the design engineer is to make things difficult for the fabricator and impossible for the serviceman.
To spot the expert, pick the one who predicts the job will take the longest and cost the most.
If you can't understand it, it is intuitively obvious.
If it's not in the computer, it doesn't exist.
If an experiment works, something has gone wrong.
When all else fails, read the instructions.
If there is a possibility of several things going wrong the one that will cause the most damage will be the one to go wrong.
Everything that goes up must come down.
Any instrument when dropped will roll into the least accessible corner.
Any simple theory will be worded in the most complicated way.
The degree of technical competence is inversely proportional o the level of management.

title: Abbott's Admonitions
laws: If you have to ask, you're not entitled to know.
If you don't like the answer, you shouldn't have aked the question.

title: Abrams's Advice
law: When eating an elephant, take one bite at a time.

title: Rule of Accuracy
law: When working toward the solution of a problem, it always helps if you know the answer.

corollary.law: Provided, of course, that you know there is a problem.

title: Acheson's Rule of the Bureaucracy
law: A memorandum is written not to inform the reader but to protect the writer.

title: Acton's Law
law: Power tends to corrupt; absolute power corrupts absolutely.

title: Ade's Law
law: Anybody can win -- unless there happens to be a second entry.

title: Airplane Law
law: When the plane you are on is late, the plane you want to transfer to is on time.

title: Alan's Law of Research
law: The theory is supported as long as the funds are.

title: Agnes Allen's Law
law: Almost anything is easier to get into than out of.

title: Allen's Axiom
law: When all else fails, follow instructions.

title: Alley's Axiom
law: Justice always prevails... three times out of seven.

title: Anderson's Law
law: Any system or program, however complicated, if looked at in exactly the right way, will become even more complicated.

title: Law of Annoyance
law: When working on a project, if you put away a tool that you're certain you're finished with, you will need it instantly.

title: Anthony's Law of the Workshop
law: Any tool, when dropped, will roll into the least accessible corner of the workshop.

corollary.law: On the way to the corner, any dropped tool will first always strike your toes.

title: Laws of Applied Confusion
law: The one piece that the plant forgot to ship is the one that supports 75% of the balance of the shipment.

corollary.law: Not only did the plant forget to ship it, 50% of the time they haven't even made it.

title: Approval Seeker's Law
law: Those whose approval you seek the most give you the least.

title: Army Axiom
law: Any order that can be misunderstood has been misunderstood.

title: Army Law
law: If it moves, salute it; if it doesn't move, pick it up; if you can't pick it up, paint it.

title: Ashley-Perry Statistical Axioms
laws: Numbers are tools, not rules.
Numbers are symbols for things; the number and the thing are not the same.
Skill in manipulating numbers is a talent, not evidence of divine guidance.
Like other occult techniques of divination, the statistical method has a private jargon deliberately contrived to obscure its methods from nonpractitioners.
The product of an arithmetical computation is the answer to an equation; it is not the solution to a problem.

title: Babcock's Law
law: If it can be borrowed and it can be broken, you will borrow it and you will break it.

title: Bagdikian's Law of Editor's Speeches
law: The splendor of an editor's speech and the splendor of his newspaper are inversely related to the distance between the city in which he makes his speech and the city in which he publishes his paper.

title: Baker's Byroad
law: When you are over the hill, you pick up speed.

title: Baldy's Law
law: Some of it plus the rest of it is all of it.

title: Barber's Laws of Backpacking
laws: The integral of the gravitational potential taken around any loop trail you chose to hike always comes out positive.
Any stone in your boot always migrates against the pressure gradient to exactly the point of most pressure.
The weight of your pack increases in direct proportion to the amount of food you consume from it. If you run out of food, the pack weight goes on increasing anyway.
The number of stones in your boot is directly proportional to the number of hours you have been on the trail.
The difficulty of finding any given trail marker is directly proportional to the importance of the consequences of failing to find it.
The size of each of the stones in your boot is directly proportional to the number of hours you have been on the trail.
The remaining distance to your chosen campsite remains constant as twilight approaches.
The net weight of your boots is proportional to the cube of the number of hours you have been on the trail.
When you arrive at your chosen campsite, it is full.
If you take your boots off, you'll never get them back on again.
The local density of mosquitos is inversely proportional to your emaining repellent.

title: Barrett's Laws of Driving
laws: The vehicle in front of you is traveling slower than you are.
This lane ends in 500 feet.

title: Barr's Comment on Domestic Tranquility
law: On a beautiful day like this it's hard to believe anyone can be unhappy -- but we'll work on it.

title: Barth's Distinction
law: There are two types of people: those who divide people into two types, and those who don't.

title: Bartz's Law of Hokey Horsepuckery
law: The more ridiculous a belief system, the higher the probability of its success.

title: Baruch's Rule for Determining Old Age
law: Old age is always fifteen years older than I am.

title: Forthoffer's Cynical Summary of Barzun's Laws
laws: That which has not yet been taught directly can never be taught directly.
If at first you don't succeed, you will never succeed.

title: Baxter's First Law
law: Government intervention in the free market always leads to a lower national standard of living.

title: Baxter's Second Law
law: The adoption of fractional gold reserves in a currency system always leads to depreciation, devaluation, demonetization and, ultimately, to complete destruction of that currency.

title: Baxter's Third Law
law: In a free market good money always drives bad money out of circulation.

title: Becker's Law
law: It is much harder to find a job than to keep one.

title: Belle's Constant
law: The ratio of time involved in work to time available for work is usually about 0.6.

title: Benchley's Law
law: Anyone can do any amount of work, provided it isn't the work he is supposed to be doing at that moment.

title: Berkeley's Laws
laws: The world is more complicated than most of our theories make it out to be.
Ignorance is no excuse.
Most problems have either many answers or no answer. Only a few problems have a single answer.
An answer may be wrong, right, both, or neither. Most answers are partly right and partly wrong.
A chain of reasoning is no stronger than its weakest link.
A statement may be true independently of illogical reasoning.
Most general statements are false, including this one.
An exception TESTS a rule; it NEVER PROVES it.
The moment you have worked out an answer, start checking it -- it probably isn't right.
If there is an opportunity to make a mistake, sooner or later the mistake will be made.
Being sure mistakes will occur is a good frame of mind for catching them.
Check the answer you have worked out once more -- before you tell it to anybody.
Estimating a figure may be enough to catch an error.
Figures calculated in a rush are very hot; they should be allowed to cool off a little before being used; thus we will have a reasonable time to think about the figures and catch mistakes.
A great many problems do not have accurate answers, but do have approximate answers, from which sensible decisions can be made.

title: Berra's Law
law: You can observe a lot just by watching.

title: Berson's Corollary of Inverse Distances
law: The farther away from the entrance that you have to park, the closer the space vacated by the car that pulls away as you walk up to the door.

title: Billings's Law
law: Live within your income, even if you have to borrow to do so.

title: Blaauw's Law
law: Established technology tends to persist in spite of new technology.

title: Blanchard's Newspaper Obituary Law
law: If you want your name spelled wrong, die.

title: Bok's Law
law: If you think education is expensive -- try ignorance.

title: Boling's Postulate
law: If you're feeling good, don't worry. You'll get over it.

title: Bolton's Law of Ascending Budgets
law: Under current practices, both expenditures and revenues rise to meet each other, no matter which one may be in excess.

title: Bombeck's Rule of Medicine
law: Never go to a doctor whose office plants have died.

title: Boob's Law
law: You always find something the last place you look.

title: Booker's Law
law: An ounce of application is worth a ton of abstraction.

title: Boozer's Revision
law: A bird in the hand is dead.

title: Boren's Laws of the Bureaucracy
laws: When in doubt, mumble.
When in trouble, delegate.
When in charge, ponder.

title: Borkowski's Law
law: You can't guard against the arbitrary.

title: Borstelmann's Rule
law: If everything seems to be coming your way, you're probably in the wrong lane.

title: Boston's Irreversible Law of Clutter
law: In any household, junk accumulates to fill the space available for its storage.

title: Boultbee's Criterion
law: If the converse of a statement is absurd, the original statement is an insult to the intelligence and should never have been said.

title: Boyle's Laws
laws: When things are going well, someone will inevitably experiment detrimentally.
The deficiency will never show itself during the dry runs.
Information travels more surely to those with a lesser need to know.
An original idea can never emerge from committee in the original.
When the product is destined to fail, the delivery system will perform perfectly.
The crucial memorandum will be snared in the out-basket by the paper clip of the overlying correspondence and go to file.
Success can be insured only by devising a defense against failure of the contingency plan.
Performance is directly affected by the perversity of inanimate objects.
If not controlled, work will flow to the competent man until he submerges.
The lagging activity in a project will invariably be found in the area where the highest overtime rates lie waiting.
Talent in staff work or sales will recurringly be interpreted as managerial ability.
The "think positive" leader tends to listen to his subordinates' premonitions only during the postmortems.
Clearly stated instructions will consistently produce multiple interpretations.
On successive charts of the same organization the number of boxes will never decease.

title: Branch's First Law of Crisis
law: The spirit of public service will rise, and the bureaucracy will multiply itself much faster, in time of grave national concern.

title: First Law of Bridge
law: It's always the partner's fault.

title: Brien's First Law
law: At some time in the life cycle of virtually every organization, its ability to succeed in spite of itself runs out.

title: Broder's Law
law: Anybody that wants the presidency so much that he'll spend two years organizing and campaigning for it is not to be trusted with the office.

title: Brontosaurus Principle
law: Organizations can grow faster than their brains can manage them in relation to their environment and to their own physiology; when this occurs, they are an endangered species.

title: Brooks's Law
law: Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later.

title: (Jerry) Brown's Law
law: Too often I find that the volume of paper expands to fill the available briefcases.

title: (Sam) Brown's Law
law: Never offend people with style when you can offend them with substance.

title: (Tony) Brown's Law of Business Success
law: Our customer's paperwork is profit. Our own paperwork is loss.

title: Bruce-Briggs's Law of Traffic
law: At any level of traffic, any delay is intolerable.

title: Buchwald's Law
law: As the economy gets better, everything else gets worse.

title: Bucy's Law
law: Nothing is ever accomplished by a reasonable man.

title: Bunuel's Law
law: Overdoing things is harmful in all cases, even when it comes to efficiency.

title: Bureaucratic Cop-Out
law: You should have seen it when *I* got it.

title: Burns's Balance
law: If the assumptions are wrong, the conclusions aren't likely to be very good.

title: Bustlin' Billy's Bogus Beliefs
laws: The organization of any program reflects the organization of the people who develop it.
There is no such thing as a "dirty capitalist", only a capitalist.
Anything is possible, but nothing is easy.
Capitalism can exist in one of only two states -- welfare or warfare.
I'd rather go whoring than warring.
History proves nothing.
There is nothing so unbecoming on the beach as a wet kilt.
A little humility is arrogance.
A lot of what appears to be progess is just so much technological rococo.

title: Butler's Law of Progress
law: All progress is based on a universal innate desire on the part of every organism to live beyond its income.

title: Bye's First Law of Model Railroading
law: Anytime you wish to demonstrate something, the number of faults is proportional to the number of viewers.

title: Bye's Second Law of Model Railroading
law: The desire for modeling a prototype is inversely proportional to the decline of the prototype.

title: Cahn's Axiom (Allen's Axiom)
law: When all else fails, read the instructions.

title: Calkin's Law of Menu Language
law: The number of adjectives and verbs that are added to the description of a menu item is in inverse proportion to the quality of the resulting dish.

title: John Cameron's Law
law: No matter how many times you've had it, if it's offered, take it, because it'll never be quite the same again.

title: Camp's Law
law: A coup that is known in advance is a coup that does not take place.

title: Campbell's Law
law: Nature abhors a vacuous experimenter.

title: Canada Bill Jones's Motto
law: It's morally wrong to allow suckers to keep their money.

title: Canada Bill Jones's Supplement
law: A Smith and Wesson beats four aces.

title: Cannon's Cogent Comment
law: The leak in the roof is never in the same location as the drip.

title: Cannon's Comment
law: If you tell the boss you were late for work because you had a flat tire, the next morning you will have a flat tire.
Carson's Law It's better to be rich and healthy than poor and sick.

title: Cartoon Laws
laws: Any body suspended in space will remain in space until made aware of its situation. Daffy Duck steps off a cliff, expecting further pastureland. He loiters in midair, soliloquizing flippantly, until he chances to look down. At this point, the familiar principle of 32 feet per second per second takes over.

Any body in motion will tend to remain in motion until solid matter intervenes suddenly. Whether shot from a cannon or in hot pursuit on foot, cartoon characters are so absolute in their momentum that only a telephone pole or an outsize boulder retards their forward motion absolutely. Sir Isaac Newton called this sudden termination of motion the stooge's surcease.

Any body passing through solid matter will leave a perforation conforming to its perimeter. Also called the silhouette of passage, this phenomenon is the speciality of victims of directed-pressure explosions and of reckless cowards who are so eager to escape that they exit directly through the wall of a house, leaving a cookie-cutout- perfect hole. The threat of skunks or matrimony often catalyzes this reaction.

The time required for an object to fall twenty stories is greater than or equal to the time it takes for whoever knocked it off the ledge to spiral down twenty flights to attempt to capture it unbroken. Such an object is inevitably priceless, the attempt to capture it inevitably unsuccessful.

All principles of gravity are negated by fear. Psychic forces are sufficient in most bodies for a shock to propel them directly away from the earth's surface. A spooky noise or an adversary's signature sound will induce motion upward, usually to the cradle of a chandelier, a treetop, or the crest of a flagpole. The feet of a character who is running or the wheels of a speeding auto need never touch the ground, especially when in flight.

As speed increases, objects can be in several places at once. This is particularly true of tooth-and-claw fights, in which a character's head may be glimpsed emerging from the cloud of altercation at several places simultaneously. This effect is common as well among bodies that are spinning or being throttled. A 'wacky' character has the option of self- replication only at manic high speeds and may ricochet off walls to achieve the velocity required.

Certain bodies can pass through solid walls painted to resemble tunnel entrances; others cannot. This trompe l'oeil inconsistency has baffled generation, but at least it is known that whoever paints an entrance on a wall's surface to trick an opponent will be unable to pursue him into this theoretical space. The painter is flattened against the wall when he attempts to follow into the painting. This is ultimately a problem of art, not of science.

Any violent rearrangement of feline matter is impermanent. Cartoon cats possess even more deaths than the traditional nine lives might comfortably afford. They can be decimated, spliced, splayed, accordion-pleated, spindled, or disassembled, but they cannot be destroyed. After a few moments of blinking self pity, they reinflate, elongate, snap back, or solidify.

title: Cavanaugh's Postulate
law: All kookies are not in a jar.

title: Law of Character and Appearance
law: People don't change; they only become more so.

title: Checkbook Balancer's Law
law: In matters of dispute, the bank's balance is always smaller than yours.

title: Cheops's Law
law: Nothing ever gets built on schedule or within budget.

title: Chili Cook's Secret
law: If your next pot of chili tastes better, it probably is because of something left out, rather than added.

title: Chisholm's First Law and Corollary
law: see Murphy's Third and Fifth Laws.

title: Chisholm's Second Law
law: When things are going well, something will go wrong.

corollaries.law: When things just can't get any worse, they will.
Anytime things appear to be going better, you haveoverlooked something.

title: Chisholm's Third Law
law: Proposals, as understood by the proposer, will be judged otherwise by others.

corollaries.law: If you explain so clearly that nobody can misunderstand, somebody will.
If you do something which you are sure will meet with everyone's approval, somebody won't like it.
Procedures devised to implement the purpose won't quite work.
No matter how long or how many times you explain, no one is litening.

title: The First Discovery of Christmas Morning
law: Batteries not included.

title: Churchill's Commentary on Man
law: Man will occasionally stumble over the truth, but most of the time he will pick himself up and continue on as though nothing has happened.

title: Ciardi's Poetry Law
law: Whenever in time, and wherever in the universe, any man speaks or writes in any detail about the technical management of a poem, the resulting irascibility of the reader's response is a constant.

title: Clarke's First Law
law: When a distinguished but elderly scientist states that something is possible, he is almost certainly right. When he states that something is impossible, he is very probably wrong.

corollary.title: Asimov
corollary.law: When the lay public rallies round an idea that is denounced by distinguished but elderly scientists, and supports that idea with great fervor and emotion -- the distinguished ut elderly scientists are then, after all, right.

title: Clarke's Second Law
law: The only way to discover the limits of the possible is to go beyond them into the impossible.

title: Clarke's Third Law
law: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.

title: Clarke's Law of Revolutionary Ideas
law: Every revolutionary idea -- in Science, Politics, Art or Whatever -- evokes three stages of reaction. They may be summed up by the three phrases: It is completely impossible -- don't waste my time. It is possible, but it is not worth doing. I said it was a good idea all along.

title: Clark's First Law of Relativity
law: No matter how often you trade dinner or other invitations with in-laws, you will lose a small fortune in the exchange.

corollary.law: Don't try it: you cannot drink enough of your in-laws' booze to get even before your liver fails.

title: Clark's Law
law: It's always darkest just before the lights go out.

title: Cleveland's Highway Law
law: Highways in the worst need of repair naturally have low traffic counts, which results in low priority for repair work.

title: Clopton's Law
law: For every credibility gap there is a gullibility fill.

title: Clyde's Law
law: If you have something to do, and you put it off long enough, chances are someone else will do it for you.

title: Cohen's Law
law: What really matters is the name you succeed in imposing on the facts -- not the facts themselves.

laws.title: Law of Alienation
laws.law: Nothing can so alienate a voter from the political system as backing a winning candidate.

laws.title: Law of Ambition
laws.law: At any one time, thousands of borough councilmen, school board members, attorneys, and businessmen -- as well as congressmen, senators, and governors -- are dreaming of the White House, but few, if any of them, will make it.

laws.title: Law of Attraction
laws.law: Power attracts people but it cannot hold them.

laws.title: Law of Competition
laws.law: The more qualified candidates who are available, the more likely the compromise will be on the candidate whose main qualification is a nonthreatening incompetence.

laws.title: Law of Inside Dope
laws.law: There are many inside dopes in politics and government.

laws.title: Law of Lawmaking
laws.law: Those who express random thoughts to legislative committees are often surprised and appalled to find themselves the instigators of law.

laws.title: Law of Permanence
laws.law: Political power is as permanent as today's newspaper. Ten years from now, few will know or care who the most powerful man in any state was today.

laws.title: Law of Secrecy
laws.law: The best way to publicize a governmental or political action is to attempt to hide it.

laws.title: Law of Wealth
laws.law: Victory goes to the candidate with the most accumulated or contributed wealth who has the financial resources to convince the middle class and poor that he will be on their side.

laws.title: Law of Wisdom
laws.law: Wisdom is considered a sign of weakness by the powerful because a wise man can lead without power but only a powerful man can lead without wisdom.

title: Cohn's Law
law: The more time you spend in reporting on what you are doing, the less time you have to do anything. Stability is achieved when you spend all your time doing nothing but reporting on the nothing you are doing.

title: Cole's Law
law: Thinly sliced cabbage.

title: Mr. Cole's Axiom
law: The sum of the intelligence on the planet is a constant; the population is growing.

title: Colson's Law
law: If you've got them by the balls, their hearts and minds will follow.

title: Comins's Law
law: People will accept your idea much more readily if you tell them Benjamin Franklin said it first.

title: Committee Rules
laws: Never arrive on time, or you will be stamped a beginner.
Don't say anything until the meeting is half over; this stamps you as being wise.
Be as vague as possible; this prevents irritating the others.
When in doubt, suggest that a subcommittee be appointed.
Be the first to move for adjournment; this will make you opular -- it's what everyone is waiting for.

title: Commoner's Three Laws of Ecology
laws: No action is without side-effects.
Nothing ever goes away.
There is no free lunch.

title: Law of Computability
law: Any system or program, however complicated, if looked at in exactly the right way, will become even more complicated.

title: Law of Computability Applied to Social Science
law: If at first you don't succeed, transform your data set.

title: Laws of computer programming:
laws: Any given program, when running, is obsolete.
Any given program costs more and takes longer.
If a program is useful, it will have to be changed.
If a program is useless, it will have to be documented.
Any program will expand to fill available memory.
The value of a program is proportional to the weight of its output.
Program complexity grows until it exceeds the capabilities of the programmer who must maintain it.
Any non-trivial program contains at least one bug.
Undetectable errors are infinite in variety, in contrast to detectable errors, which by definition are limited.
Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later.

title: Lubarsky's Law of Cybernetic Entomology
law: There's aways one more bug.

title: First Maxim of Computers
law: To err is human, but to really screw things up requires a computer.

title: Connolly's Law of Cost Control
law: The price of any product produced for a government agency will be not less than the square of the initial Firm Fixed-Price Contract.

title: Connolly's Rule for Political Incumbents
law: Short-term success with voters on any side of a given issue can be guaranteed by creating a long-term special study commission made up of at least three divergent interest groups.

title: Conrad's Conundrum
law: Technologie don't transfer.

title: Considine's Law
law: Whenever one word or letter can change the entire meaning of a sentence, the probability of an error being made will be in direct proportion to the embarrassment it will cause.

title: Conway's Law 1
law: If you assign N persons to write a compiler you'll get a N-1 pass compiler.

title: Conway's Law 2
law: In every organization there will always be one person who knows what is going on. This person must be fired.

title: Cooke's Law
law: In any decisive situation, the amount of relevant information available is inversely proportional to the importance of the decision.

title: Cook's Law
law: Much work, much food; little work, little food; no work, burial at sea.

title: Coolidge's Immutable Observation
law: When more and more people are thrown out of work, unemployment results.

title: Cooper's Law
law: All machines are amplifiers.

title: Cooper's Metalaw
law: A proliferation of new laws creates a proliferation of new loopholes.

title: Mr. Cooper's Law
law: If you do not understand a particular word in a piece of technical writing, ignore it. The piece will make perfect sense without it.

title: Corcoroni's Laws of Bus Transportation
laws: The bus that left the stop just before you got there is your bus.
The amount of time you have to wait for a bus is directly proportional to the inclemency of the weather.
All buses heading in the opposite direction drive off the face of the earth and never return.
The last rush-hour express bus to your neighborhood leaves five minutes before you get off work.
Bus schedules are arranged so your bus will arrive at the transfer point precisely one minute after the connecting bus has left.
Any bus that can be the wrong bus will be the wrong bus. All others are out of service or full.

title: Cornuelle's Law
law: Authority tends to assign jobs to those least able to do them.

title: Corry's Law
law: Paper is always strongest at the perforations.

title: Courtois's Rule
law: If people listened to themselves more often, they'd talk less.

title: Crane's Law (Friedman's Reiteration)
law: There ain't no such thing as a free lunch. ("tanstaafl")

title: Mark Miller's Exception to Crane's Law
law: There are no "free lunches", but sometimes it costs more to collect money than to give away food.

title: Crane's Rule
law: There are three ways to get something done: do it yourself, hire someone, or forbid your kids to do it.

title: Cripp's Law
law: When traveling with children on one's holidays, at least one child of any number of children will request a rest room stop exactly halfway between any two given rest areas.

title: Cropp's Law
law: The amount of work done varies inversely with the amount of time spent in the office.

title: Culshaw's First Principle of Recorded Sound
law: Anything, no matter how bad, will sound good if played back at a very high level for a short time.

title: Cutler Webster's Law
law: There are two sides to every argument unless a man is personally involved, in which case there is only one.

title: Czecinski's Conclusion
law: There is only one thing worse than dreaming you are at a conference and waking to find that you are at a conference, and that is the conference where you can't fall asleep.

title: Darrow's Observation
law: History repeats itself. That's one of the things wrong with history.

title: Darwin's Observation
law: Nature will tell you a direct lie if she can.

title: Dave's Law of Advice
law: Those with the best advice offer no advice.

title: Dave's Rule of Street Survival
law: Speak softly and own a big, mean Doberman.

title: Davidson's Maxim
law: Democracy is that form of government where everybody gets what the majority deserves.

title: Davis's Basic Law of Medicine
law: Pills to be taken in twos always come out of the bottle in threes.

title: de la Lastra's Law
law: After the last of 16 mounting screws has been removed from an access cover, it will be discovered that the wrong access cover has been removed.

corollary.law: After an access cover has been secured by 16 hold-down screws, it will be discovered that the gasket has been ommitted.

title: Deadlock's Law
law: If the law-makers make a compromise, the place where it will be felt most is the taxpayer's pocket.

corollary.law: The compromise will always be more expensive than either of the suggestions it is compromising.

title: Dean's Law of the District of Columbia
law: Washington is a much better place if you are asking questions rather than answering them.

title: First Law of Debate
law: Never argue with a fool. People might not know the difference.

title: Decaprio's Rule
law: Everything takes more time and money.

title: Deitz's Law of Ego
law: The fury engendered by the misspelling of a name in a column is in direct ratio to the obscurity of the mentionee.

title: Dennis's Principles of Management by Crisis
laws: To get action out of management, it is necessary to create the illusion of a crisis in the hope it will be acted upon.
Management will select actions or events and convert them to crises. It will then over-react.
Management is incapable of recognizing a true crisis.
The squeaky hinge gets the oil.

title: Dhawan's Laws for the Non-Smoker
laws: The cigarette smoke always drifts in the direction of the non-smoker regardless of the direction of the breeze.
The amount of pleasure derived from a cigarette is directly proportional to the number of non-smokers in the vicinity.
A smoker is always attracted to the non-smoking section.
The life of a cigarette is directly proportional to the itensity of the protests from non-smokers.

title: Dieter's Law
law: Food that tastes the best has the highest number of calories.

title: Dijkstra's Prescription for Programming Inertia
law: If you don't know what your program is supposed to do, you'd better not start writing it.

title: Diogenes's First Dictum
law: The more heavily a man is supposed to be taxed, the more power he has to escape being taxed.

title: Diogenes's Second Dictum
law: If a taxpayer thinks he can cheat safely, he probably will.

title: Dirksen's Three Laws of Politics
laws: Get elected.
Get re-elected.
Don't get mad --get even.

title: Principle of Displaced Hassle
law: To beat the bureaucracy, make your problem their problem.

title: Donohue's Law
law: Anything worth doing is worth doing for money.

title: Donsen's Law
law: The specialist learns more and more about less and less until, finally, he knows everything about nothing; whereas the generalist learns less and less about more and more until, finally, he knows nothing about everything.

title: Laws of Dormitory Life
laws: The amount of trash accumulated within the space occupied is exponentially proportional to the number of living bodies that enter and leave within any given amount of time.

Since no matter can be created or destroyed (excluding nuclear and cafeteria substances), as one attempts to remove unwanted material (i.e., trash) from one's living space, the remaining material mutates so as to occupy 30 to 50 percent more than its original volume. Corollary: Dust breeds.
The odds are 6:5 that if one has late classes, one's roommate will have the earliest possible classes.
Corollary 1: One's roommate (who has early classes) has an alarm clock that is louder than God's own.
Corollary 2: When one has an early class, one's roommate will invariably enter the space late at nightand suddenly become hyperactive, ill, violent, or all three.

title: Douglas's Law of Practical Aeronautics
law: When the weight of the paperwork equals the weight of the plane, the plane will fly.

title: Dow's Law
law: In a hierarchical organization, the higher the level, the greater the confusion.

title: Dror's First Law
law: While the difficulties and dangers of problems tend to increase at a geometric rate, the knowledge and manpower qualified to deal with these problems tend to increase linearly.

title: Dror's Second Law
law: While human capacities to shape the environment, society, and human beings are rapidly increasing, policymaking capabilities to use those capacities remain the same.

title: Ducharme's Precept
law: Opportunity always knocks at the least opportune moment.

title: Dude's Law of Duality
law: Of two possible events, only the undesired one will occur.

title: Dunne's Law
law: The territory behind rhetoric is too often mined with equivocation.

title: Dunn's Discovery
law: The shortest measurable interval of time is the time between the moment one puts a little extra aside for a sudden emergency and the arrival of that emergency.

title: Durant's Discovery
law: One of the lessons of history is that nothing is often a good thing to do and always a clever thing to say.

title: Durrell's Parameter
law: The faster the plane, the narrower the seats.

title: Dyer's Law
law: A continuing flow of paper is sufficient to continue the flow of paper.

title: Economists' Laws
laws: What men learn from history is that men do not learn from history.
If on an actuarial basis there is a 50-50 chance that something willgo wrong, it will actually go wrong nine times out of ten.

title: Edington's Theory
law: The number of different hypotheses erected to explain a given biological phenomenon is inversely proportional to the available knowledge.

title: Law of Editorial Correction
law: Anyone nit-picking enough to write a letter of correction to an editor doubtless deserves the error that provoked it.

title: Ehrlich's Rule
law: The first rule of intelligent tinkering is to save all the parts.

title: Ehrman's Commentary
law: Things will get worse before they will get better. Who said things would get better?

title: Eliot's Observation
law: Nothing is so good as it seems beforehand.

title: Ellenberg's Theory
law: One good turn gets most of the blanket.

title: Emerson's Insight
law: That which we call sin in others is experiment for us.

title: Old Engineer's Law
law: The larger the project or job, the less time there is to do it.

title: The "Enough Already" Law
law: The more you run over a dead cat, the flatter it gets.

title: Extended Epstein-Heisenberg Principle
law: In an R & D orbit, only 2 of the existing 3 parameters can be defined simultaneously. The parameters are: task, time, and resources ($). 1) If one knows what the task is, and there is a time limit allowed for the completion of the task, then one cannot guess how much it will cost. 2) If the time and resources ($) are clearly defined, then it is impossible to know what part of the R & D task will be performed. 3) If you are given a clearly defined R & D goal and a definte amount of money which has been calculated to be necessary for the completion of the task, one cannot predict if and when the goal will be reached. 4) If one is lucky enough to be able to accurately define all three parameters, then what one is dealing with is not in the realm of R & D.

title: Epstein's Law
law: If you think the problem is bad now, just wait until we've solved it.

title: Ettorre's Observation
law: The other line moves faster.

corollary.law: Don't try to change lines. The other line -- the one you were in originally -- will then move faster.

title: Evans's Law of Politics
law: When team members are finally in a position to help the team, it turns out they have quit the team.

title: Evelyn's Rules for Bureaucratic Survival
laws: A bureaucrat's castle is his desk... and parking place. Proceed cautiously when changing either.

On the theory that one should never take anything for granted, follow up on everything, but especially those items varying from the norm. The greater the divergence from normal routine and/or the greater the number of offices potentially involved, the better the chance a never-to-be-discovered person will file the problem away in a drawer specifically designed for items requiring a decision.
Never say without qualification that your activity has sufficient space, money, staff, etc.

Always distrust offices not under your jurisdiction which say that they are there to serve you. "Support" offices in a bureaucracy tend to grow in size and make demands on you out of proportion to their service, and in the end require more effort on your part than their service is worth. Corollary: Support organizations can always prove success by showing service to someone... not necessarily you.
Incompetents often hire able assistants.

title: Everitt's Form of the Second Law of Thermodynamics
law: Confusion (entropy) is always increasing in society. Only if someone or something works extremely hard can this confusion be reduced to order in a limited region. Nevertheless, this effort will stil result in an increase in the total confusion of society at large.

title: Eve's Discovery
law: At a bargain sale, the only suit or dress that you like best and that fits is the one not on sale.

corollary.title: Adam's Corollary
corollary.law: It's easy to tell when you've got a bargain -- it doesn't fit.

title: Nonreciprocal Laws of Expectations
laws: Negative expectations yield negative results.
Positive expectations yield negative results.

title: First Law of Expert Advice
law: Don't ask the barber whether you need a haircut.

title: Faber's Laws
laws: If there isn't a law, there will be.
The number of errors in any piece of witing rises in proportion to the writer's reliance on secondary sources.

title: Fairfax's Law
law: Any facts which, when included in the argument, give the desired result, are fair facts for the argument.

title: Falkland's Rule
law: When it is not necessary to make a decision, it is necessary not to make a decision.

title: Farber's First Law
law: Give him an inch and he'll screw you.

title: Farber's Second Law
law: A hand in the bush is worth two anywhere else.

title: Farber's Third Law
law: We're all going down the same road in different directions.

title: Farber's Fourth Law
law: Necessity is the mother of strange bedfellows.

title: Farnsdick's corollary
law: After things have gone from bad to worse, the cycle will repeat itself.

title: Farrow's Finding
law: If God had intended for us to go to concerts, He would have given us tickets.

title: Law of Fashion
law: Any given dress is: indecent 10 years before its time, daring 1 year before its time, chic in its time, dowdy 3 years after its time, hideous 20 years after its time, amusing 30 years after its time, romantic 100 years after its time, and beautiful 150 years after its time.

title: Rule of Feline Frustration
law: When your cat has fallen asleep on your lap and looks utterly content and adorable, you will suddenly have to go to the bathroom.

title: Fetridge's Law
law: Important things that are supposed to happen do not happen, especially when people are looking.

title: Fett's Law of the Lab
law: Never replicate a successful experiment.

title: The Fifth Rule
law: You have taken yourself too seriously.

title: Finagle's Creed
law: Science is Truth. Don't be misled by fact.

title: Finagle's First Law
law: If an experiment works, something has gone wrong.

title: Finagle's Second Law
law: No matter what result is anticipated, there will always be someone eager to (a) misinterpret it, (b) fake it, or (c) believe it happened according to his own pet theory.

title: Finagle's Third Law
law: In any collection of data, the figure most obviously correct, beyond all need of checking, is the mistake.

corollaries.law: No one whom you ask for help will see it.
Everyone who stops by with unsought advice ill see it immediately.

title: Finagle's Fourth Law
law: Once a job is fouled up, anything done to improve it only makes it worse.

title: Finagle's Law According to Niven
law: The perversity of the universe tends to a maximum.

title: Finagle's Laws of Information
laws: The information you have is not what you want.
The information you want is not what you need.
The information you need is not what you can obtain.
The information you can obtain costs more than you wat to pay.

title: Finagle's Rules
law: Ever since the first scientific experiment, man has been plagued by the increasing antagonism of nature. It seems only right that nature should be logical and neat, but experience has shown that this is not the case. A further series of rules has been formulated, designed to help man accept the pigheadedness of nature.
laws: To study a subject best, understand it thoroughly before you start.
Always keep a record of data. It indicates you've been working.
Always draw your curves, then plot the reading.
In case of doubt, make it sound convincing.
Experiments should be reproducible. They should all fail in the same way.
When you don't know what you are doing, do it neatly.
Teamwork is essential; it allows you to blame someone else.
Always verify your witchcraft.
Be sure to obtain meteorological data before leaving on vacation.
Do not believe in miracles. Rely on them.

title: Fishbein's Conclusion
law: The tire is only flat on the bottom.

title: Fitz-Gibbon's Law
law: Creativity varies inversely with the number of cooks involved with the broth.

title: Flap's Law
law: Any inanimate object, regardless of its composition or configuration, may be expected to perform at any time in a totally unexpected manner for reasons that are either entirely obscure or completely mysterious.

title: Ford Pinto Rule
law: Never buy a car that has a wick.

title: Fortis's Three Great Lies of Life
laws: Money isn't everything.
It's great to be a Negro.
I'm only going to put it i a little way.

title: Three Lies According to Playboy
laws: The check's in the mail.
Anticipation is half the fun.
I promise I won't come in yourmouth.

title: Hare's Additional Lie
law: This will hurt me more than it hurts you.

corollary.title: Lowry's Additional Lie
corollary.law: I've never done this before.

title: Foster's Law
law: If you cover a congressional committee on a regular basis, they will report the bill on your day off.

title: Fowler's Law
law: In a bureaucracy, accomplishment is inversely proportional to the volume of paper used.

title: Fowler's Note
law: The only imperfect thing in nature is the human race.

title: Frankel's Law
law: Whatever happens in government could have happened differently, and it usually would have been better if it had.

corollary.law: Once things have happened, no matter how accidentally, they will be regarded as manifestations of an unchangeable Higher Reason.

title: Franklin's Observation
law: He that lives upon Hope dies farting.

title: Franklin's Rule
law: Blessed is he who expects nothing, for he shall not be disappointed.

title: Freeman's Law
law: Nothing is so simple it cannot be misunderstood.

title: Freemon's Rule
law: Circumstances can force a generalized incompetent to become competent, at least in a specialized field.

title: Fried's Law
law: Ideas endure and prosper in inverse proportion to their soundness and validity.

title: Laws of the Frisbee
laws: The most powerful force in the world is that of a disc straining to land under a car, just beyond reach. (The technical term for this force is "car suck".)
The higher the quality of a catch or the comment it receives, the greater the probability of a crummy return throw. ("Good catch. . . Bad throw.")
One must never precede any maneuver by a comment more predictive than, "Watch this!" (Keep 'em guessing.)
The higher the costs of hitting any object, the greater the certainty it will be struck. (Remember: The disk is positive; cops and old ladies are clearly negative.)
The best catches are never seen. ("Did you see that?" "See what?")
The greatest single aid to distance is for the disc to be going in a direction you did not want. (Wrong way = long way.)
The most powerful hex words in the sport are: "I really have this down -- watch." (Know it? Blow it!)
In any crowd of spectators at least one will suggest that razor blades could be attached to the disc. ("You could maim and kill with that thing.")
The greater your need to make a good catch, the greater the probability your partner will deliver his worst throw. (If you can't touch it, you can't trick it.)
The single most difficult move with a disc is to put it down. ("Just one more!")

title: Frisch's Law
law: You cannot have a baby in one month by getting nine women pregnant.

title: Frothingham's Fallacy
law: Time is money.

title: Fudd's First Law of Opposition
law: If you push something hard enough, it will fall over.

title: Teslacle's Deviant to Fudd's Law
law: It goes in -- it must come out.

title: Funkhouser's Law of the Power of the Press
law: The quality of legislation passed to deal with a problem is inversely proportional to the volume of media clamor that brought it on.

title: Futility Factor (Carson's Consolation)
law: No experiment is ever a complete failure -- it can always serve as a bad example, or the exception that proves the rule (but only if it is the first experiment in the series).

title: Fyffe's Axiom
law: The problem-solving process will always break down at the point at which it is possible to determine who caused the problem.

title: Gadarene Swine Law
law: Merely because the group is in formation does not mean that the group is on the right course.

title: Galbraith's Law of Political Wisdom
law: Anyone who says he isn't going to resign, four times, definitely will.

title: Galbraith's Law of Prominence
law: Getting on the cover of "Time" guarantees the existence of opposition in the future.

title: Gallois's Revelation
law: If you put tomfoolery into a computer, nothing comes out but tomfoolery. But this tomfoolery, having passed through a very expensive machine, is somehow ennobled, and no one dares to criticize it.

corollary.law: An expert is a person who avoids the small errors while sweeping on to the Grand Fallacy.

title: Laws of Gardening
laws: Other people's tools work only in other people's yards.
Fancy gizmos don't work.
If nobody uses it, there's a reason.
You get the most of what you need theleast.

title: Gardner's Rule of Society
law: The society which scorns excellence in plumbing because plumbing is a humble activity and tolerates shoddiness in philosophy because it is an exalted activity will have neither good plumbing nor good philosophy. Neither its pipes nor its theories will hold water.

title: Gell-Mann's Dictum
law: Whatever isn't forbidden is required.

corollary.law: If there's no reason why something shouldn't exist, then it must exist.

title: Law of Generalizations
law: All generalizations are false.

title: Gerrold's Fundamental Truth
law: It's a good thing money can't buy happiness. We couldn't stand the commercials.

title: Gerrold's Law
law: A little ignorance can go a long way.

corollary.title: Lyall's Addendum
corollary.law: ...in the direction of maximum harm.

title: Gerrold's Pronouncement
law: The difference between a politician and a snail is that a snail leaves its slime behind.

title: Gerrold's Laws of Infernal Dynamics
laws: An object in motion will be heading in the wrong direction.
An object at rest will be in the wrong place.

title: Gerrold's Laws of Infernal Dynamics
laws: An object in motion will always be headed in the wrong direction.
An object at rest will always be in the wrong place.
The energy required to change either one of the state will always be more than you wish to expend, but never so much as to make the task totally impossible.

title: Getty's Reminder
law: The meek shall inherit the earth, but NOT its mineral rights.

title: Gibb's Law
law: Infinity is one lawyer waiting for another.

title: Gilb's Laws of Unreliability (see also Troutman's Laws of Computer Programming)

laws.law: Computers are unreliable, but humans are even more unreliable.
laws.corollary: At the source of every error which is blamed on the computer you will find at least two human errors, including the error of blaming it on the computer.

laws: Any system which depends on human reliability is unreliable.
The only difference between the fool and the criminal who attacks a system is that the fool attacks unpredictably and on a broader front.
A system tends to grow in terms of complexity rather than of simplification, until the resulting unreliability becomes intolerable.
Self-checking systems tend to have a complexity in proportion to the inherent unreliability of the system in which they are used.
The error-detection and correction capabilities of any system will serve as the key to understanding the type of errors which they cannot handle.
Undetectable errors are infinite in variety, in contrast to detectable errors, which by definition are limited.
All real programs contain errors until proved otherwise -- which is impossible.
Investment in reliability will increase until it exceeds the probable cost of erors, or somebody insists on getting some useful work done.

title: Gilmer's Motto for Political Leadership
law: Look over your shoulder now and then to be sure someone's following you.

title: Ginsberg's Theorem (Generalized Laws of Thermodynamics)
laws: You can't win.
You can't break even.
You can't even quit th game.

title: Ehrman's Commentary on Ginberg's Theorem
laws: Things will get worse before they get better.
Who said things would get better?

title: Freeman's Commentary on Ginberg's Theorem
law: Every major philosophy that attempts to make life seem meaningful is based on the negation of one part of Ginsberg's Theorem. To wit
laws: Capitalism is based on the assumption that you can win.
Socialism is based on the assumption that you can break even.
Mysticism is based on the assumption that you can quit the gam.

title: Glatum's Law of Materialistic Acquisitiveness
law: The perceived usefulness of an article is inversely proportional to its actual usefulness once bought and paid for.

title: Godin's Law
law: Generalizedness of incompetence is directly proportional to highestness in hierarchy.

title: Golden Principle
law: Nothing will be attempted if all possible objections must first be overcome.

title: The Golden Rule of Arts and Sciences
law: Whoever has the gold makes the rules.

title: Gold's Law
law: If the shoe fits, it's ugly.

title: (Bill) Gold's Law
law: A column about errors will contain errors.

title: (Vic) Gold's Law
law: The candidate who is expected to do well because of experience and reputation (Douglas, Nixon) must do better than well, while the candidate expected to fare poorly (Lincoln, Kennedy) can put points on the media board simply by surviving.

title: Goldwyn's Law of Contracts
law: A verbal contract isn't worth the paper it's written on.

title: Golub's Laws of Computerdom
laws: Fuzzy project objectives are used to avoid the embarrassment of estimating the corresponding costs.
A carelessly planned project takes three times longer to complete than expected; a carefully planned project takes only twice as long.
The effort requires to correct course increases geometrically with time.
Project teams detest weekly progress reporting because it so vividly maniests their lack of progress.

title: The 19 Rules for good Riting
laws: Each pronoun agrees with their antecedent.
Just between you and I, case is important.
Verbs has to agree with their subject.
Watch out for irregular verbs which has cropped up into our language.
Don't use no double negatives.
A writer mustn't shift your point of view.
When dangling, don't use participles.
Join clauses good like a conjunction should.
And don't use conjunctions to start sentences.
Don't use a run-on sentence you got to punctuate it.
About sentence fragments.
In letters themes reports articles and stuff like that we use commas to keep strings apart.
Don't use commas, which aren't necessary.
Its important to use apostrophe's right.
Don't abbrev.
Check to see if you any words out.
In my opinion I think that the author when he is writing should not get into the habit of making use of too many unnecessary words which he does not really need.
Then, of course, there's that old one: Never use a preposition to end a sentence with.
Last but not least, avoid cliches like the plague.

title: Goodfader's Law
law: Under any system, a few sharpies will beat the rest of us.

title: Goodin's Law of Conversions
law: The new hardware will break down as soon as the old is disconnected and out.

title: Gordon's First Law
law: If a research project is not worth doing, it is not worth doing well.

title: Professor Gordon's Rule of Evolving Bryophytic Systems
law: While bryophytic plants are typically encountered in substrata of earthy or mineral matter in concreted state, discrete substrata elements occasionally display a roughly spherical configuration which, in presence of suitable gravitational and other effects, lends itself to combined translatory and rotational motion. One notices in such cases an absence of the otherwise typical accretion of bryophyta. We conclude therefore that a rolling stone gathers no moss.

title: Corollary (Rutgers)
law: Generally the subjective value assignable to avian lifeforms, when encountered and considered within the confines of certain orders of woody plants lacking true meristematic dominance, as compared to a possible valuation of these same lifeforms when in the grasp of -- and subject to control by -- the manipulative bone/muscle/nerve complex typically terminating the forelimb of a member of the species homo sapiens (and possibly direct precursors thereof) is approximately five times ten to th minus first power.

title: Goulden's Law of Jury Watching
law: If a jury in a criminal trial stays out for more than 24 hours, it is certain to vote acquittal, save in those instances when it votes guilty.

title: Graditor's Laws
laws: If it can break, it will, but only after the warranty expires.
A necessary item goes on sale only after you have purchased it a the regular price.

title: Gray's Law of Bilateral Asymmetry in Networks
law: Information flows efficiently through organizations, except that bad news encounters high impedance in flowing upward.

title: Gray's Law of Programming
law: n+1 trivial tasks are expected to be accomplished in the same time as n trivial tasks. Logg's Rebuttal to Gray's Law of Programming: n+1 trivial tasks take twice as long as n trivial tasks.

title: Rule of the Great
law: When someone you greatly admire and respect appears to be thinking deep thoughts, they are probably thinking about lunch.

title: Greenberg's First Law of Influence
law: Usefulness is inversely proportional to reputation for being useful.

title: Greener's Law
law: Never argue with a man who buys ink by the barrel.

title: Greenhaus's Summation
law: I'd give my right arm to be ambidextrous.

title: Gresham's Law
law: Trivial matters are handled promptly; important matters are never resolved.

title: Grosch's Law
law: Computing power increases as the square of the cost. If you want to do it twice as cheaply, you have to do it four times slower.

title: Gross's Law
law: When two people meet to decide how to spend a third person's money, fraud will result.

title: Grossman's Misquote
law: Complex problems have simple, easy to understand wrong answers.

title: Gummidge's Law
law: The amount of expertise varies in inverse proportion to the number of statements understood by the general public.

title: Gumperson's Law
law: The probability of anything happening is in inverse ratio to its desirability.

corollaries.law: After a salary raise, you will have less money at the end of the month than you had before.
The more a recruit knows about a given subject, the better chance he has of being assigned to something else.

You can throw a burnt match out the window of your car and start a forest fire, but you can use two boxes of matches and a whole edition of the Sunday paper without being able to start a fire under the dry logs in your fireplace.
Children have more energy after a hard day of play than they do after a good night's sleep.
The person who buys the most raffle tickets has the least chance of winning.
Good parking places are always on the other side of the street.

title: Gumperson's Proof
law: The most undesirable things are the most certain (death and taxes).

title: Guthman's Law of Media
law: Thirty seconds on the evening news is worth a front page headline in every newspaper in the world.

title: Hacker's Law
law: The belief that enhanced understanding will necessarily stir a nation or an organization to action is one of mankind's oldest illusions.

title: Hacker's Law of Personnel
law: Anyone having supervisory responsibility for the completion of a task will invariably protest that more resources are needed.

title: Hagerty's Law
law: If you lose your temper at a newspaper columnist, he'll get rich or famous or both.

title: Haldane's Law
law: The Universe is not only queerer than we imagine, it is queerer than we CAN imagine.

title: Hale's Rule
law: The sumptuousnss of a company's annual report is in inverse proportion to its profitability that year.

title: Hall's Law
law: There is a statistical correlation between the number of initials in an Englishman's name and his social class (the upper class having significantly more than three names, while members of the lower class average 2.6).

title: Halpern's Observation
law: That tendency to err that programmers have been noticed to share with other human beings has often been treated as if it were an awkwardness attendant upon programming's adolescence, which like acne would disappear with the craft's coming of age. It has proved otherwise.

title: Harden's Law
law: Every time you come up with a terrific idea, you find that someone else thought of it first.

title: Hardin's Law
law: You can never do merely one thing.

title: Harper's Magazine's Law
law: You never find an article until you replace it.

title: Harris's Lament
law: All the good ones are taken.

title: Harris's Law
law: Any philosophy that can be put "in a nutshell" belongs there.

title: Harris's Restaurant Paradox
law: One of the greatest unsolved riddles of restaurant eating is that the customer usually gets faster service when the retaurant is crowded than when it is half empty; it seems that the less the staff has to do, the slower they do it.

title: Harrison's Postulate
law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite criticism.

title: Hartig's How Is Good Old Bill? We're Divorced Law
law: If there is a wrong thing to say, one will.

title: Hartig's Sleeve in the Cup, Thumb in the Butter Law
law: When one is trying to be elegant and sophisticated, one won't.

title: Hartley's Law
law: You can lead a horse to water, but if you can get him to float on his back you've got something.

title: Hartley's Second Law
law: Never go to bed with anybody crazier than you are.

title: Hartman's Automotive Laws
laws: Nothing minor ever happens to a car on the weekend.
Nothing minor ever happens to a car on a trip.
Nothing minor ever happens to a car.

title: Hart's Law
law: In a country as big as the United States, you can find fifty examples of anything.

title: Harver's Law
law: A drunken man's words are a sober man's thoughts.

title: Hawkin's Theory of Progress
law: Progress does not consist of replacing a theory that is wrong with one that is right. It consists of replacing a theory that is wrong with one that is more subtly wrong.

title: Hein's Law
law: Problems worthy of attack prove their worth by hitting back.

title: Heller's Myths of Management
law: The first myth of management is that it exists. The second myth of management is that success equals skill.

title: Corollary (Johnson)
law: Nobody really knows what is going on anywhere within your organization.

title: Hellrung's Law
law: If you wait, it will go away. (Shevelson's Extension:... having done its damage.) [Grelb's Addition:... if it was bad, it will be back.

title: Hendrickson's Law
law: If a problem causes many meetings, the meetings eventually become more important than the problem.

title: Herblock's Law
law: If it's good, they'll stop making it.

title: Herrnstein's Law
law: The total attention paid to an instructor is a constant regardless of the size of the class.

title: Hersh's Law
law: Biochemistry expands to fill the space and time available for its completion and publication.

title: Hildebrand's Law
law: The quality of a department is inversely proportional to the number of courses it lists in its catalogue.

title: Historian's Rule
law: Any event, once it has occurred, can be made to appear inevitable by a competent historian.

title: Hoare's Law of Large Programs
law: Inside every large program is a small program struggling to get out.

title: Hogg's Law of Station Wagons
law: The amount of junk is in direct proportion to the amount of space available.

title: Baggage Corollary
law: If you go on a trip taking two bags with you, one containing everything you need fo the trip and the other containing absolutely nothing, the second bag will be completely filled with junk acquired on the trip when you return.

title: Horner's Five Thumb Postulate
law: Experience varies directly with equipment ruined.

title: Horngren's Observation
law: (generalized) The real world is a special case.

title: Horowitz's Rule
law: A computer makes as many mistakes in two seconds as 20 men working 20 years.

title: Howard's First Law of Theater
law: Use it.

title: Howe's Law
law: Every man has a scheme that will not work.

title: Hull's Theorem
law: The combined pull of several patrons is the sum of their separate pulls multiplied by the number of patrons.

title: Hull's Warning
law: Never insult an alligator until after you have crossed the river.

title: IBM Pollyanna Principle
law: Machines should work. People should think.

title: Idea Formula
law: One man's brain plus one other will produce about one half as many ideas as one man would have produced alone. These two plus two more will produce half again as many ideas. These four plus four more begin to represent a creative meeting, and the ratio changes to one quarter as many.

title: The Ike Tautology
law: Things are more like they are now than they have ever been before.

corollary.law: Nostalgia isn't what it used to be.

title: Iles's Law
law: There is an easier way to do it.

corollaries.law: When looking directly at the easier way, especially for long periods, you will not see it.
Neither will Iles.

title: Imhoff's Law
law: The organization of any bureaucracy is very much like a septic tank -- the REALLY big chunks always rise to the top.

title: Index of Development
law: The degree of a country's development is measured by the ratio of the price of an automobile to the cost of a haircut. The lower the ratio, the higher the degree of development.

title: Law of the Individual
law: Nobody really cares or understands what anyone else is doing.

title: Laws of Institutional Food
laws: Everything is cold except what should be.
Everything, including the corn flakes, is geasy.

title: Law of Institutions
law: The opulence of the front office decor varies inversely with the fundamental solvency of the firm.

title: Iron Law of Distribution
law: Them what has -- gets.

title: Wakefield's Refutation of the Iron Law of Distribution
law: Them what gets -- has.

title: Issawi's Law of Aggression
law: At any given moment, a society contains a certain amount of accumulated and accruing aggressiveness. If more than 21 years elapse without this aggressiveness being directed outward, in a popular war against other countries, it turns inward, in social unrest, civil disturbances, and political disruption.

title: Issawi's Laws of Committo-Dynamics
laws: Comitas comitatum, omnia comitas.
The less you enjoy serving on commitees, the more likely you are to be pressed to do so.

title: Issawi's Law of the Conservation of Evil
law: The total amount of evil in any system remains constant. Hence, any diminution in one direction -- for instance, a reduction in poverty or unemployment -- is accompanied by an increase in another, e.g., crime or air pollution.

title: Issawi's Law of Consumption Patterns
law: Other people's patterns of expenditure and consumption are highly irrational and slightly immoral.

title: Issawi's Law of Cynics
law: Cynics are right nine times out of ten; what undoes them is their belief that they are right ten times out of ten.

title: Issawi's Law of Dogmatism
law: When we call others dogmatic, what we really object to is their holding dogmas that are different from our own.

title: Issawi's Law of Estimation of Error
law: Experts in advanced countries underestimate by a factor of 2 to 4 the ability of people in underdeveloped countries to do anything technical.

title: Issawi's Law of Frustration
law: One cannot make an omelette without breaking eggs -- but it is amazing how many eggs one can break without making a decent omelette.

laws.title: The Path of Progress
laws.law: A shortcut is the longest distance between two points.

laws.title: The Pace of Progress
laws.law: Society is a mule, not a car... If pressed too hard, it will kick and throw off its rider.

title: Issawi's Law of the Social Sciences
law: By the time a social science theory is formulated in such a way that it can be tested, changing circumstances have already made it obsolete.

title: Issawi's Observation on the Consumption of Paper
law: Each system has its own way of consuming vast amounts of paper: in socialist societies by filling large forms in quadruplicate, in capitalist societies by putting up huge posters and wrapping every article in four layers of cardboard.

title: First Postulate of Isomorphism
law: Things equal to nothing else are equal to each other.

title: Italian Proverb
law: She who is silent consents.

title: Jacquin's Postulate on Democratic Governments
law: No man's life, liberty or property are safe while the legislature is in session.

title: Jake's Law
law: Anything hit with a big enough hammer will fall apart.

title: Jaroslovsky's Law
law: The distance you have to park from your apartment increases in proportion to the weight of packages you are carrying.

title: Jay's Laws of Leadership
laws: Changing things is central to leadership, and changing them before anyone else is creativity.

To build something that endures, it is of the greatest important to have a long tenure in offic -- to rule for many years. You can achieve a quick success in a year or two, but nearly all of the great tycoons have continued their building much longer.

title: Jenkinson's Law
law: It won't work.

title: Jinny's Law
law: There is no such thing as a short beer. (As in, "I'm going to stop off at Joe's for a short beer before on the way home.")

title: John's Axiom
law: When your opponent is down, kick him.

title: John's Collateral Corollary
law: In order to get a loan you must first prove you don't need it.

title: Johnson's First Law
law: When any mechanical contrivance fails, it will do so at the most inconvenient possible time.

title: Johnson's Second Law
law: If, in the course of several months, only three worthwhile social events take place, they will all fall on the same evening.

title: Johnson's Third Law
law: If you miss one issue of any magazine, it will be the issue containing the article, story, or installment you were most anxious to read.

corollary.law: All of your friends either missed it, lost it, or threw it out.

title: Johnson's First Law of Auto Repair
law: Any tool dropped while repairing an automobile will roll under the car to the vehicle's exact geographic center.

title: Johnson-Laird's Law
law: Toothache tends to start on Saturday night.

title: Jones's Law
law: The man who can smile when things go wrong has thought of someone he can blame it on.

title: Jones's Motto
law: Friends may come and go, but enemies accumulate.

corollary.title: McClaughry's Codicil on Jones's Motto:
corollary.law: To make an enemy, do someone a favor.

title: Jones's Principle
law: Needs are a function of what other people have.

title: Juhani's Law
law: The compromise will always be more expensive than either of the suggestions it's compromising.

title: Kafka's Law
law: In the fight between you and the world, back the world.

title: Kamin's First Law
law: All currencies will decrease in value and purchasing power over the long term, unless they are freely and fully convertable into gold and that gold is traded freely without restrictions of any kind.

title: Kamin's Second Law
law: Threat of capital controls accelerates marginal capital outflows.

title: Kamin's Third Law
law: Combined total taxation from all levels of government will always increase (until the government is replaced by war or revolution).

title: Kamin's Fourth Law
law: Government inflation is always worse than statistics indicat: central bankers are biased toward inflation when the money unit is non-convertible, and without gold or silver backing.

title: Kamin's Fifth Law
law: Purchasing power of currency is always lost far more rapidly than ever regained. (Those who expect even fluctuations in both directions play a losing game.)

title: Kamin's Sixth Law
law: When attempting to predict and forecast macro-economic moves or economic legislation by a politician, never be misled by what he says; instead watch what he does.

title: Kamin's Seventh Law
law: Politicians will always inflate when given the opportunity.

title: Kaplan's Law of the Instrument
law: Give a small boy a hammer and he will find that everything he encounters needs pounding.

title: Katz's Law
law: Men and nations will act rationally when all other possibilities have been exhausted.

title: Katz's Maxims
laws: Where are the calculations that go with the calculated risk?

Inventing is easy for staff outfits. Stating a problem is much harder. Instead of stating problems, people like to pass out half- accurate statements together with half-available solutions which they can't finish and which they want you to finish.

Every organization is self-perpetuating. Don't ever ask an outfit to justify itself, or you'll be covered with facts, figures, and fancy. The criterion should rather be, "What will happen if the outfit stops doing what it's doing?" The value of an organization is more easily determined this way.
Try to find out who's doing the work, not who's writing about it, controlling it, or summarizing it.
Watch out for formal briefings; they often produce an avalanche (a high-level snow job of massive and overwhelming proportions).

The difficulty of the coordination task often blinds one to the fact that a fully coordinated piece of paper is not supposed to be either the major or the final product of the organization, but it often turns out that way.

Most organizations can't hold more than one idea at a time. Thus complementary ideas are always regarded as competetive. Further, like a quantized pendulum, an organization can jump from one extreme to the other, without ever going through the middle.

title: Try to find the real tense of the report you are reading
law: Was it done, is it being done, or is it something to be done? Reports are now written in four tenses: past tense, present tense, future tense, and pretense. Watch for novel use of "contractor grammar", defined by the imperfect past, the insufficient present, and the absolutely perfect future.

title: Kelley's Law
law: Last guys don't finish nice.

title: Kelly's Law
law: An executive will always return to work from lunch early if no one takes him.

title: Kennedy's Law
law: Excessive official restraints on information are inevitably self-defeating and productive of headaches for the officials concerned.

title: Kent's Law
law: The only way a reporter should look at a politician is down.

title: Kerr-Martin Law
laws: In dealing with their own problems, faculty members are the most extreme conservatives.
In dealing with other people's problems, they are the world's most extreme liberals.

title: Kettering's Laws
laws: If you want to kill any idea in the world today, get a committee working on it.
If you have always done it that way, it is probably wrong.

title: Key to Status
law: S = D/K. S is the status of a person in an organization, D is the number of doors he must open to perform his job, and K is the number of keys he carries. A higher number denotes higher status. Thus the janitor needs to open 20 doors and has 20 keys (S = 1), a secretary has to open two doors with one key (S = 2), but the president never has to carry any keys since there is always someone around to open doors for him (with K = 0 and a high D, his S reaches infinity).

title: Kharasch's Institutional Imperative
law: Every action or decision of an institution must be intended to keep the institution machinery working.

corollary.law: The expert judgment of an institution, when the matter involved concerns continuation of the institution's operations, is totally predictable, and hence the finding is totally worthless.

title: Kirkland's Law
law: The usefulness of any meeting is in inverse proportion to the attendance.

title: Kitman's Law
law: On the TV screen, pure drivel tends to drive off ordinary drivel.

title: Klipstein's Lament
law: All warranty and guarantee clauses are voided by payment of the invoice.

title: Klipstein's Observation
law: Any product cut to length will be too short.

title: Klipstein's Law of Specifications
law: In specifications, Murphy's Law supersedes Ohm's.

title: Klipstein's Laws
law: Applied to General Engineering
laws: A patent application will be preceded by one week by a similar application made by an independent worker.
Firmness of delivery dates is inversely proportional to the tightness of the schedule.
Dimensions will always be expressed in the least usable term. Velocity, for example, will be expressed in furlongs per fortnight.
Any wire cut to length will be too short.

title: Applied to Prototyping and Production
laws: Tolerances will accumulate unidirectionally toward maximum difficulty to assemble.
If a project requires n components, there will be n-1 units in stock.
A motor will rotate in the wrong direction.
A failsafe circuit will destroy others.
A transistor protected by a fast-acting fuse will protect the fuse by blowing first.
A failure will not appear until a unit has passed final inspection.
A purchased component or instrument will meet its specs long enough, and only long enough, to pass incoming inspection.
After the last of 16 mounting screws has been removed from an access cover, it will be discovered that the wrong access cover has been removed.
After an access cover has been secured by 16 hold-down screws, it will be discovered that the gasket has been omitted.
After an instrument has been assembled, extra components will be found on the bench.

title: Knight's Law
law: Life is what happens to you while you are making other plans.

title: Knoll's Law of Media Accuracy
law: Everything you read in the newspapers is absolutely true except for that rare story of which you happen to have firsthand knowledge.

title: Knowles's Law of Legislative Deliberation
law: The length of debate varies inversely with the complexity of the issue.

corollary.law: When the issue is trivial, and everyone understands it, debate is almost interminable.

title: Kohn's Second Law
law: Any experiment is reproducible until another laboratory tries to repeat it.

title: Koppett's Law
