law: Whatever creates the greatest inconvenience for the largest number must happen.

title: Korman's conclusion
law: The trouble with resisting temptation is it may never come your way again.

title: Kristol's Law
law: Being frustrated is disagreeable, but the real disasters in life begin when you get what you want.

title: Krueger's Observation
law: A taxpayer is someone who does not have to take a civil service exam in order to work for the government.

title: Labor Law
law: A disagreeable law is its own reward.

title: First Law of Laboratory Work
law: Hot glass looks exactly the same as cold glass.

title: LaCombe's Rule of Percentages
law: The incidence of anything worthwhile is either 15-25 percent or 80-90 percent.

corollary.title: Dudenhoefer
corollary.law: An answer of 50 percent will suffice for the 40-60 range.

title: Langin's Law
law: If things were left to chance, they'd be better.

title: Langsam's Law
law: Everything depends.

title: Lani's Principles of Economics
laws: Taxes are not levied for the benefit of the taxed.
$100 placed at 7% interest compounded quarterly for 200 years will increase to more than $100,000,000 by which time it will be worth nothing.
In God we trust; all others pay cash.

title: La Rochefoucauld's Law
law: It is more shameful to distrust one's friends than to be deceived by them.

title: Law of Late-Comers
law: Those who have the shortest distance to travel invariably arrive latest.

title: Laura's Law
law: No child throws up in the bathroom.

title: Lawyer's Rule
law: When the law is against you, argue the facts. When the facts are against you, argue the law. When both are against you, call the other lawyer names.

title: Leahy's Law
law: If a thing is done wrong often enough, it becomes right.

corollary.law: Volume is a defense to error.

title: Le Chatelier's Law
law: If some stress is brought to bear on a system in equilibrium, the equilibrium is displaced in the direction which tends to undo the effect of the stress.

title: Lenin's Law
law: Whenever the cause of the people is entrusted to professors, it is lost.

title: Le Pelley's Law
law: The bigger the man, the less likely he is to object to caricature.

title: Les Miserables Metalaw
law: All laws, whether good, bad, or indifferent, must be obeyed to the letter.

title: Levy's Ten Laws of the Disillusionment of the True Liberal
laws: Large numbers of things are determined, and therefore not subject to change.
Anticipated events never live up to expectations.
That segment of the community with which one has the greatest sympathy as a liberal inevitably turns out to be one of the most narrow-minded and bigoted segments of the community.

Always pray that your opposition be wicked. In wickedness there is a strong strain toward rationality. Therefore there is always the possibility, in theory, of handling the wicked by outthinking them.
Corollary 1: Good intentions randomize behavior.
Corollary 2: Good intentions are far more difficult to cope with than malicious intent.
Corollary 3: If good intentions are combined with stupidity, it is impossible to outthink them.
Corollary 4: Any discovery is more likely to be exploited by the wicked than applied by the virtous.
In unanimity there is cowardice and uncritical thinking.
To have a sense of humor is to be a tragic figure.
To know thyself is the ultimate form of aggression.
No amount of genius can overcome a preoccupation with detail.
Only God can make a random selection.
Eternal boredom is the price of constat vigilance.

title: Lewis's Laws
laws: People will buy anything that's one to a customer.
No matter how long or how hard you shop for an item,after you've bought it it will be on sale somewhere cheaper.

title: Liebling's Law
law: If you just try long enough and hard enough, you can always manage to boot yourself in the posterior.

title: Lilly's Metalaw
law: All laws are simulations of reality.

title: Lloyd-Jones's Law of Leftovers
law: The amount of litter on the street is proportional to the local rate of unemployment.

title: Law of Local Anesthesia
law: Never say "oops" in the operating room.

title: (F)law of Long-Range Planning
law: The longer ahead you plan a special event, and the more special it is, the more likely it is to go wrong.

title: Long's Notes
laws: Always store beer in a dark place.
Certainly the game is rigged. Don't let that stop you; if you don't bet, you can't win.
Any priest or shaman must be presumed guilty until proved innocent.
Always listen to experts. They'll tell you what can't be done, and why. Then do it.
If it can't be expressed in figures, it is not science; it is opinion.
It has long been known that one horse can run faster than another -- but which one? Differences are crucial.
A fake fortuneteller can be tolerated. But an authentic soothsayer should be shot on sight. Cassandra did not get half the kicking around she deserved.
Delusions are often functional. A mother's opinions about her children's beauty, intelligence, goodness, et cetera ad nauseam, keep her from drowning them at birth.
A generation which ignores history has no past -- and no future.
A poet who reads his verse in public may have other nasty habits.
Small change can often be found under seat cushions.

History does not record anywhere at any time a religion that has any rational basis. Religion is a crutch for people not strong enough to stand up to the unknown without help. But, like dandruff, most people do have a religion and spend time and money on it and seem to derive considerable pleasure from fiddling with it.
It's amazing how much "mature wisdom" resembles being too tired.
Of all the strange "crimes" that human beings have legislated out of nothing, "blasphemy" is the most amazing -- with "obscenity" and "indecent exposure" fighting it out for second and third place.
It's better to copulate than never.
Everything in excess! To enjoy the flavor of life, take big bites. Moderation is for monks.
It may be better to be a live jackal than a dead lion, but it is better still to be a live lion. And usually easier.
Never appeal to a man's "better nature". He may not have one. Invoking his self-interest gives you more leverage.
Avoid making irrevocable decisions while tired or hungry.
An elephant: A mouse built to government specifications.
A zygote is a gamete's way of producing more gametes. This may be the purpose of the universe.

Stupidity cannot be cured with money, or through education, or by legislation. Stupidity is not a sin; the victim can't help being stupid. But stupidity is the only universal capital crime; the sentence is death, there is no appeal, and execution is carried out automatically and without pity.

God is omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent. It says so right here on the label. If you have a mind capable of believing all three of these divine attributes simultaneously, I have a wonderful bargain for you. No checks, please. Cash and in small bills.
Beware of altruism. It is based on self-deception, the root of all evil.
Never underestimate the power of human stupidity.
Always tell her she is beautiful, especially if she is not.
In a family argument, if it turns out you are right, apologize at once.
To stay young requires unceasing cultivation of the ability to unlearn old falsehoods.
Does history record any case in which the majority was right?
Secrecy is the beginning of tyranny.
The greatest productive force is human selfishness.
Be wary of strong drink. It can make you shoot at tax collectors -- and miss.
Expertise in one field does not carry over into other fields. But experts often think so. The narrower their field of knowledge the more likely they are to think so.
Never try to outstubborn a cat.
Tilting at windmills hurts you more than the windmills.
Yield to temptation; it may not pass your way again.
Waking a person unnecessarily should not be considered a capital crime. For a first offense, that is.

The correct way to punctuate a sentence that starts "Of course it's none of my business, but... " is to place a period after the word "but". Don't use excessive force in supplying such a moron with a period. Cutting his throat is only a momentary pleasure and is bound to get you talked about.
A skunk is better company than a person who prides himself on being "frank".
Natural laws have no pity.
You can go wrong by being too skeptical as readily as by being too trusting.
Anything free is worth what you pay for it.
Climate is what we expect; weather is what we get.

Pessimist by policy, optimist by temperament -- it is possible to be both. How? By never taking an unnecessary chance and by minimizing risks you can't avoid. This permits you to play out the game happily, untroubled by the certainty of the outcome.
"I came, I saw, SHE conquered." (The original Latin seems to have been garbled.)
A committee is a life form with six or more legs and no brain.
Don't try to have the last word. You might get it.

title: Los Angeles Dodgers Law
law: Wait till last year.

title: Law of the Lost Inch
law: In designing any type of construction, no overall dimension can be totalled correctly after 4:40 p.m. on Friday.

corollaries.law: Under the same conditions, if any minor dimensions are given to sixteenths of an inch, they cannot be totalled at all.
The correct total will become self-evident at 9:01 a.m. on Monday.

title: Lowrey's Law
law: If it jams, force it. If it breaks, it needed replacing anyway.

title: Lowrey's Law of Expertise
law: Just when you get really good at something, you don't need to do it any more.

title: Lubarsky's Law of Cybernetic Entomology
law: There's always one more bug.

title: Lubin's Law
law: If another scientist thought your research was more important than his, he would drop what he is doing and do what you are doing.

title: Luce's Law
law: No good deed goes unpunished.

title: Lucy's Law
law: The alternative to getting old is depressing.

title: Luten's Laws
laws: When properly administered, vacations do not diminish productivity: for every week you're away and get nothing done, there's another week when your boss is away and you get twice as much done.
It's not so hard to lift yourself by your bootstraps once you're off the ground.

title: Lyall's Conjecture
law: If a computer cable has one end, then it has another.

title: Lyall's Fundamental Observation
law: The most important leg of a three legged stool is the one that's missing.

title: Lynch's Law
law: When the going gets tough, everybody leaves.

title: Lyon's Law of Hesitation
law: He who hesitates is last.

title: Madison's Question
law: If you have to travel on a Titanic, why not go first-class?

title: Rev. Mahaffy's Observation
law: There's no such thing as a large whiskey.

title: Maier's Law
law: If the facts do not conform to the theory, they must be disposed of.

corollaries.law: The bigger the theory, the better.

corollaries.title: Compensation Corollary
corollaries.law: The experiment may be considered a success if no more than 50% of the observed measurements must be discarded to obtain a correspondence with the theory.

title: Malek's Law
law: Any simple idea will be worded in the most complicated way.

title: Malinowski's Law
law: Looking from far above, from our high places of safety in the developed civilization, it is easy to see all the crudity and irrelevance of magic.

title: Malloy's Maxim
law: The fact that monkeys have hands should give us pause.

title: The first Myth of Management
law: It exists.

title: Truths of Management
laws: Think before you act; it's not your money.
All good management is the expression of one great idea.
No executive devotes effort to proving himself wrong.
Cash in must exceed cash out.
Management capability is always less than the organization actually needs.
Either an executive can do his job or he can't.
If sophisticated calculations are needed to justify an action, don't do it.
If you are doing something wrong, you will do it badly.
If you are attempting the impossible, you will fail.
The easiest way of making money is to stop losing it.

title: Truth 5.1 of Management
law: Organizations always have too many managers.

title: Manly's Maxim
law: Logic is a systematic method of coming to the wrong conclusion with confidence.

title: Marshall's Generalized Iceberg Theorem
law: Seven-eighths of everything can't be seen.

title: Marshall's Universal Laws of Perpetual Perceptual Obfuscation
laws: Nobody perceives anything with total accuracy.
No two people perceive the same thing identically.
Few perceive what difference it makes -- or care.

title: Martha's Maxim (and see Olum's Observation and Farrow's Finding)
law: If God had meant for us to travel tourist class, He would have made us narrower.

title: Dean Martin's Definition of Drunkenness
law: You're not drunk if you can lie on the floor without holding on.

title: Martin-Berthelot Principle
law: Of all possible committee reactions to any given agenda item, the reaction that will occur is the one which will liberate the greatest amount of hot air.

title: Martin's Laws of Academia
laws: The faculty expands its activity to fit whatever space is available, so that more space is always required.
Faculty purchases of equipment and supplies always increase to match the funds available, so these funds are never adequate.
The professional quality of the faculty tends to be inversely proportional to the importance it attaches to space and equipmet.

title: Martin's Law of Committees
law: All committee reports conclude that "it is not prudent to change the policy (or procedure, or organization, or whatever) at this time."

corollary.title: Martin's Exclusion
corollary.law: Committee reports dealing with wages, salaries, fringe benefits, facilities, computers, employee parking, libraries, coffee breaks, secretarial support, etc., always call for dramatic expenditure increases.

title: Martin's Law of Communication
law: The inevitable result of improved and enlarged communication between different levels in a hierarchy is a vastly increased area of misunderstanding.

title: Martin's Minimax Maxim
law: Everyone knows that the name of the game is to let the other guy have all of the little tats and to keep all of the big tits for yourself.

title: Matsch's Law
law: It is better to have a horrible ending than to have horrors without end.

title: Matsch's Maxim
law: A fool in a high station is like a man on the top of a small mountain: everything appears small to him and he appears small to everybody.

title: Matz's warning
law: Beware of the physician who is great at getting out of trouble.

title: Maugham's Thought
law: Only a mediocre person is always at his best.

title: May's Law
law: The quality of the correlation is inversely proportional to the density of the control (the fewer the facts, the smoother the curves).

title: May's Mordant Maxim
law: A university is a place where men of principle outnumber men of honor.

title: McCarthy's Law
law: Being in politics is like being a football coach. You have to be smart enough to understand the game and dumb enough to think it's important.

title: McClaughry's Law of Public Policy
law: Politicians who vote huge expenditures to alleviate problems get re-elected; those who propose structural changes to prevent problems get early retirement.

title: McClaughry's Law of Zoning
law: Where zoning is not needed, it will work perfectly; where it is desperately needed, it always breaks down.

title: McDonald's Second Law
law: Consultants are mystical people who ask a company for a number and give it back to them.

title: McGoon's Law
law: The probability of winning is inversely proportional to the amount of the wager.

title: McGovern's Law
law: The longer the title, the less important the job.

title: McGurk's Law
law: Any improbable event which would create maximum confusion if it did occur, will occur.

title: McKenna's Law
law: When you are right, be logical. When you are wrong, be-fuddle.

title: McLaughlin's Law (and see Parson's Third Law)
law: The length of any meeting is inversely proportional to the length of the agenda for that meeting.

title: McLean's Maxim
law: There are only two problems with people. One is that they don't think. The other is that they do.

title: McNaughton's Rule
law: Any argument worth making within the bureaucracy must be capable of being expressed in a simple declarative sentence that is obviously true once stated.

title: Margaret Mead's Law of Human Migration
law: At least fifty percent of the human race doesn't want their mother-in-law within walking distance.

title: Melcher's Law
law: In a bureaucracy, every routing slip will expand until it contains the maximum number of names that can be typed in a single vertical column.

title: H. L. Mencken's Law
law: Those who can -- do. Those who cannot -- teach. Those who cannot teach -- administrate. (Martin's Extension)

title: Mencken's Metalaw
law: For every human problem, there is a neat, simple solution; and it is always wrong.

title: Merkin's Maxim
law: When in doubt, predict that the present trend will continue.

title: Merrill's First Corollary
law: There are no winners in life; only survivors.

title: Merrill's Second Corollary
law: In the highway of life, the average happening is of about as much true significance as a dead skunk in the middle of the road.

title: Meskimen's Laws
law: 1) When they want it bad (in a rush), they get it bad. 2) There's never time to do it right, but always time to do it over.

title: Michehl's Theorem
law: Less is more.

title: Pastore's Comment on Michehl's Theorem
law: Nothing is ultimate.

title: Mickelson's Law of Falling Objects
law: Any object that is accidentally dropped will hide under a larger object.

title: Miksch's Law
law: If a string has one end, then it has another end.

title: Miller's Law
law: You can't tell how deep a puddle is until you step into it.

title: Mills's Law of Transportation Logistics
law: The distance to the gate from which your flight departs is inversely proportional to the time remaining before the scheduled departure of the flight.

corollaries.law: This remains true even as you rush to catch the flight.
From this it follows that you are invariably rushing the wrong way.

title: MIST Law (Man In The Street)
law: The number of people watching you is directly proportional to the stupidity of your action.

title: Mobil's Maxim
law: Bad regulation begets worse regulation.

title: Moer's Truism
law: The trouble with most jobs is the resemblance to being in a sled dog team. No one gets a change of scenery, except the lead dog.

title: Money Maxim
law: Money isn't everything. (It isn't plentiful, for instance.)

title: Montagu's Maxim
law: The idea is to die young as late as possible.

title: Morley's Conclusion
law: No man is lonely while eating spaghetti.

title: Morton's Law
law: If rats are experimented upon, they will develop cancer. ("What this country needs are some stronger white rats.")

title: Mosher's Law
law: It's better to retire too soon than too late.

title: Munnecke's Law
law: If you don't say it, they can't repeat it.

title: Nader's Law
law: The speed of exit of a civil servant is directly proportional to the quality of his service.

title: NASA Skylab Rule
law: Don't do it if you can't keep it up.

title: NASA Truisms
laws: Research is reading two books that have never been read in order to write a third that will never be read.
A consultant is an ordinary person a long way from home.
Statistics are a highly logical and precise method for saing a half-truth inaccurately.

title: Law of Nations
law: In an underdeveloped country, don't drink the water; in a developed country, don't breathe the air.

title: Navy Law
law: If you can keep your head when all about you others are losing theirs, maybe you just don't understand the situation.

title: Evvie Nef's Law
law: There is a solution to every problem; the only difficulty is finding it.

title: Nessen's Law
law: Secret sources are more credible.

title: Newman's Law
law: Hypocrisy is the Vaseline of social intercourse.

title: Newton's Little-known Seventh Law
law: A bird in the hand is safer than one overhead.

title: Nick the Greek's Law
law: All things considered, life is 9-to-5 against.

title: Nienberg's Law
law: Progress is made on alternate Fridays.

title: Nies's Law
law: The effort expended by the bureaucracy in defending any error is in direct proportion to the size of the error.

title: Ninety-ninety Rule of Project Schedules
law: The first ninety percent of the task takes ninety percent of the time, and the last ten percent takes the other ninety percent.

title: Nixon's Rule
law: If two wrongs don't make a right, try three.

title: Nobel Effect
law: There is no proposition, no matter how foolish, for which a dozen Nobel signatures cannot be collected. Furthermore, any such petition is guaranteed page-one treatment in the New York Times.

title: Noble's Law of Political Imagery
law: All other things being equal, a bald man cannot be elected President of the United States.

corollary.law: Given a choice between two bald political candidates, the American people will vote for the less bald of the two.

title: North Carolina Equine Paradox
law: Vyarzerzomanimororsezassezanzerareorses?

title: No. 3 Pencil Principle
law: Make it sufficiently difficult for people to do something, and most people will stop doing it.

corollary.law: If no one uses something, it isn't needed.

title: Nursing Mother Principle
law: Do not nurse a kid who wears braces.

title: Nyquist's Theory of Equilibrium
law: Equality is not when a female Einstein gets promoted to assistant professor; equality is when a female schlemiel moves ahead as fast as a male schlemiel.

title: Oaks's Unruly Laws for Lawmakers
laws: Law expands in proportion to the resources available for its enforcement.
Bad law is more likely to be supplemented than repealed.
Social legislation cannot repeal physical laws.

title: O'Brien's First Law of Politics
law: The more campaigning, the better.

title: O'Brien's Principle (The $357.73 Theorem)
law: Auditors always reject any expense account with a bottom line divisible by five or ten.

title: O'Brien's Rule
law: Nothing is ever done for the right reason.

title: The Obvious Law
law: Actually, it only SEEMS as though you mustn't be deceived by appearances.

title: Occam's Electric Razor
law: The most difficult light bulb to replace burns out first and most frequently.

title: Occam's Razor
law: Entities ought not to be multiplied except from necessity. Reformulations
laws: The explanation requiring the fewest assumptions is the most likely to be correct.
Whenever two hypotheses cover the facts, use the simpler of the two.
Cut the crap.

title: Oesner's Law (Oeser's Law?)
law: There is a tendency for the person in the most powerful position in an organization to spend all his time serving on committees and signing letters.

title: Old and Kahn's Law
law: The efficiency of a committee meeting is inversely proportional to the number of participants and the time spent on deliberations.

title: Old Children's Law
law: If it tastes good, you can't have it. If it tastes awful, you'd better clean your plate.

title: Olum's Observation (and see Martha's Maxim and Farrow's Finding)
law: If God had intended us to go around naked, He would have made us that way.

title: Oppenheimer's Observation
law: The optimist thinks this is the best of all possible worlds, and the pessimist knows it.

title: Optimum Optimorum Principle
law: There comes a time when one must stop suggesting and evaluating new solutions, and get on with the job of analyzing and finally implementing one pretty good solution.

title: Ordering Principle
law: Those supplies necessary for yesterday's experiment must be ordered no later than tomorrow noon.

title: Orion's Law
law: Everything breaks down.

title: Orwell's Law of Bridge
law: All bridge hands are equally likely, but some are more equally likely than others.

title: Osborn's Law
law: Variables won't; constants aren't.

title: Otten's Law of Testimony
law: When a person says that, in the interest of saving time, he will summarize his prepared statement, he will talk only three times as long as if he had read the statement in the first place.

title: Otten's Law of Typesetting
law: Typesetters always correct intentional errors, but fail to correct unintentional ones.

title: Ozian Option
law: I can't give you brains, but I can give you a diploma.

title: Panic Instruction
law: When you don't know what to do, walk fast and look worried.

title: Paperboy's rule of Weather
law: No matter how clear the skies are, a thunderstorm will move in 5 minutes after the papers are delivered.

title: Paradox of Selective Equality
law: All things being equal, all things are never equal.

title: Pardo's Postulates
laws: Anything good is either illegal, immoral, or fattening.
The three faithful things in life are money, a dog, and an old woman.
Don't care if you're rich or not, as long as you live comfortably and an have everything you want.

title: Pareto's Law (The 20/80 Law)
law: 20% of the customers account for 80% of the turnover, 20% of the components account for 80% of the cost, and so forth.

title: Parker's Rule of Parliamentary Procedure
law: A motion to adjourn is always in order.

title: Parker's Law of Political Statements
law: The truth of a proposition has nothing to do with its credibility, and vice versa.

title: Parker's Third Rule of Tech Support
law: If you can't navigate a one-level, five-item phone tree, you didn't need a computer anyway.

title: Parkin's Law of Irritation
law: Anything that happens enough times to irritate you will happen at least once more.

title: Parkinson's Axioms
laws: An official wants to multiply subordinates, not rivals.
Officials make work for each other.

title: Parkinson's First Law
law: Work expands to fill the time available for its completion; the thing to be done swells in perceived importance and complexity in a direct ratio with the time to be spent in its completion.

title: Parkinson's Second Law
law: Expenditures rise to meet income.

title: Parkinson's Third Law
law: Expansion means complexity; and complexity decay.

title: Parkinson's Fourth Law
law: The number of people in any working group tends to increase regardless of the amount of work to be done.

title: Parkinson's Fifth Law
law: If there is a way to delay an important decision the good bureaucracy, public or private, will find it.

title: Parkinson's Sixth Law
law: The progress of science varies inversely with the number of journals published.

title: Parkinson's Law of Delay
law: Delay is the deadliest form of denial.

title: Parkinson's Law of Medical Research
law: Successful research attracts the bigger grant which makes further research impossible.

title: Parkinson's Law of the Telephone
law: The effectiveness of a telephone conversation is in inverse proportion to the time spent on it.

title: Parkinson's Law of 1000
law: An enterprise employing more than 1000 people becomes a self-perpetuating empire, creating so much internal work that it no longer needs any contact with the outside world.

title: Parkinson's Principle of Non-Origination
law: It is the essence of grantsmanship to persuade the Foundation executives that it was THEY who suggested the research project and that you were a belated convert, agreeing reluctantly to all they had proposed.

title: Mrs. Parkinson's Law
law: Heat produced by pressure expands to fill the mind available, from which it can pass only to a cooler mind.

title: Parson's Laws
laws: If you break a cup or plate, it will not be the one that was already chipped or cracked.
A place you want to get to is always just off the edge of the map you happen to have handy.
A meeting lasts at least 1 1/2 hours however short the agenda.

title: Dolly Parton's Principle
law: The bigger they are, the harder it is to see your shoes.

title: Pastore's Truths
laws: Even paranoids have enemies.
This job is marginally better than daytime TV.

title: On alcohol
law: four is one more than morethan enough.

title: Patricks's Theorem
law: If the experiment works, you must be using the wrong equipment.

title: Patton's Law
law: A good plan today is better than a perfect plan tomorrow.

title: Paturi Principle
law: Success is the result of behavior that completely contradicts the usual expectations about the behavior of a successful person.

corollary.law: The amount of success is in inverse proportion to the effort involved in attaining it.

title: Paul Principle
law: People become progressively less competent for jobs they once were well equipped to handle.

title: Paul's Law
law: You can't fall off the floor.

title: Paulg's Law
law: In America, it's not how much an item costs, it's how much you save.

title: Peck's Programming Postulates (Philosophic Engineering applied to programming)
laws: In any program, any error which can creep in will eventually do so.
Not until the program has been in production for at least six months will the most harmful error be discovered.
Any constants, limits, or timing formulas that appear in the computer manufacturer's literature should be treated as variables.
The most vital parameter in any subroutine stands the greatest chance of being left out of the calling sequence.
If only one compiler can be secured for a piece of hardware, the compilation times will be exorbitant.
If a test installation functions perfectly, all subsequent systems will malfunction.
Job control cards that positively cannot be arranged in improper order, will be.
Interchangeable tapes won't.
If more than one person has programmed a malfunctioning routine, no one is at fault.
If the input editor has been designed to reject all bad input, an ingenious idiot will discover a method to get bad data past it.
Duplicated object decks which test in identical fashion will not give identical results at remote sites.
Manufacturer's hardware and software support ceases with payment for the computer.

title: Peckham's Law (Beckhap's Law?)
law: Beauty times brains equals a constant.

title: Peers's Law
law: The solution to a problem changes the problem.

title: Captain Penny's Law
law: You can fool all of the people some of the time, and some of the people all of the time, but you can't fool MOM.

title: Perelman's Point
law: There is nothing like a good painstaking survey full of decimal points and guarded generalizations to put a glaze like a Sung vase on your eyeball.

title: Perkin's postulate
law: The bigger they are, the harder they hit.

title: Perlsweig's Law
law: People who can least afford to pay rent, pay rent. People who can most afford to pay rent, build up equity.

title: Persig's Postulate
law: The number of rational hypotheses that can explain any given phenomenon is infinite.

title: Law of the Perversity of Nature
law: You cannot successfully determine beforehand which side of the bread to butter.

title: Peter Principle
law: In every hierarchy, whether it be government or business, each employee tends to rise to his level of incompetence; every post tends to be filled by an employee incompetent to execute its duties.

corollaries.law: Incompetence knows no barriers of time or place.
Work is accomplished by those employees who have not yet reached their level of incompetence.
If at first you don't succeed, try something else.

title: Peter's Hidden Postulate According to Godin
law: Every employee begins at his level of competence.

title: Peter's Inversion
law: Internal consistency is valued more highly than efficiency.

title: Peter's Law of Evolution
law: Competence always contains the seed of incompetence.

title: Peter's Law of Substitution
law: Look after the molehills and the mountains will look after themselves.

title: Peter's Observation
law: Super-competence is more objectionable than incompetence.

title: Peter's Paradox
law: Employees in a hierarchy do not really object to incompetence in their colleagues.

title: Peter's Perfect People Palliative
law: Each of us is a mixture of good qualities and some (perhaps) not-so-good qualities. In considering our fellow people we should remember their good qualities and realize that their faults only prove that they are, after all, human. We should refrain from making harsh judgments of people just because they happen to be dirty, rotten, no-good sons-of-bitches.

title: Peter's Placebo
law: An ounce of image is worth a pound of performance.

corollary.title: Peter's Prognosis
corollary.law: Spend sufficient time in confirming the need and the need will disappear.

title: Peter's Rule for Creative Incompetence
law: Create the impression that you have already reached your level of incompetence.

title: Peter's Theorem
law: Incompetence plus incompetence equals incompetence.

title: Peterson's Law
law: History shows that money will multiply in volume and divide in value over the long run. Or, expressed differently, the purchasing power of currency will vary inversely with the magnitude of the public debt.

title: Phases of a Project
laws: Exultation.
Disenchantment.
Confusion.
Search for the Guilty.
Punishment of the Innocent.
Distinction for the Uninvolvd.

title: Phelps's Laws of Renovation
laws: Any renovation project on an old house will cost twice as much and take three times as long as originally estimated.
Any plumbing pipes you choose to replace during renovation will prove to be in excellent condition; those you decide t leave in place will be rotten.

title: Phelps's Law of Retributive Statistics
law: An unexpectedly easy-to-handle sequence of events will be immediately followed by an equally long sequence of trouble.

title: Theory of the International Society of Philosophic Engineering
laws: In any calculation, any error which can creep in will do so.
Any error in any calculation will be in the direction of most harm.
In any formula, constants (especially those obtained from engineering handbooks) are to be treated as variables.
The best approximation of service conditions in the laboratory will not begin to meet those conditions encountered in actual service.
The most vital dimension on any plan or drawing stands the greatest chance of being omitted.
If only one bid can be secured on any project, the price will be unreasonable.
If a test installation functions perfectly, all subsequent production units will malfunction.
All delivery promises must be multiplied by a factor of 2.0.
Major changes in construction will always be requested after fabrication is nearly completed.
Parts that positively cannot be assembled in improper order will be.
Interchangeable parts won't.
Manufacturer's specifications of performance should be multiplied by a factor of 0.5.
Salespeople's claims for performance should be multiplied by a factor of 0.25.
Installation and Operating Instructions shipped with the device will be promptly discarded by the Receiving Department.
Any device requiring service or adjustment will be least accessible.
Service Conditions as given on specifications will be exceeded.
If more than one person is responsible for a miscalculation, no one will be at fault.
Identical units which test in an identical fashion will not behave in an identical fashion in the field.
If, in engineering practice, a safety factor is set through service experience at an ultimate value, an ingenious idiot will promptly calculate a method to exceed said safety factor.
Warranty and guarantee clauses are voided by payment of the invoice.

title: Phone Booth Rule
law: A lone dime always gets the number nearly right.

title: Pierson's Law
law: If you're coasting, you're going downhill.

title: Pike Law of Punditry
law: The successful pundit is provided more opportunities to say things than he has things worth saying.

title: Axiom of the Pipe. (Trischmann's Paradox)
law: A pipe gives a wise man time to think and a fool something to stick in his mouth.

title: Plotnick's Law
law: The time of departure will be delayed by the square of the number of people involved.

title: Law of Political Erosion
law: Once the erosion of power begins, it has a momentum all its own.

title: Politicians' Rules
laws: When the polls are in your favor, flaunt them.
When the polls are overwhelmingly unfavorable, either (a) ridicule and dismiss them or (b) stress the volatility of public opinion.
When the polls are slightly unfavorable, play for sympathy as a struggling underdog.
When too close to call, be surprised at your own strength.

title: The Pollyanna Paradox
law: Every day, in every way, things get better and better; then worse again in the evening.

title: Potter's Law
law: The amount of flak received on any subject is inversely proportional to the subject's true value.

title: Poulsen's Law
law: When anything is used to its full potential, it will break.

title: Pournelle's Law of Costs and Schedules
law: Everything costs more and takes longer.

title: Powell's Law
law: Never tell them what you wouldn't do.

title: Law of Predictive Action
law: The second most powerful phrase in the world is "Watch this!" The most powerful phrase is "Oh yeah? Watch this!"

title: Preudhomme's Law of Window Cleaning
law: It's on the other side.

title: Price's Law of Politics
law: It's easier to be a liberal a long way from home.

title: Price's Law of Science
law: Scientists who dislike the restraints of highly organized research like to remark that a truly great research worker needs only three pieces of equipment -- a pencil, a piece of paper, and a brain. But they quote this maxim more often at academic banquets than at budget hearings.

title: The Principle Concerning Multifunctional Devices
law: The fewer functions any device is required to perform, the more perfectly it can perform those functions.

title: Law of Probable Dispersal
law: Whatever hits the fan will not be evenly distributed. (also known as the How Come It All Landed On Me Law)

title: Laws of Procrastination
laws: Procrastination shortens the job and places the responsibility for its termination on someone else (the authority who imposed the deadline).
It reduces anxiety by reducing the expected quality of the project from the best of all possible efforts to the best that can be expected given the limited time.
Status is gained in the eyes of others, and in one's own eyes, because it is assumed that the importance of the work justifies the stress.
Avoidance of interruptions including the assignment of other duties can be achieved, so that the obviously stressed worker can concentrate on the single effort.
Procrastination avoids boredom; one never has the feeling that there is nothing important to do.
It may eliminate the job if the need passes before the job can be done.

title: Productivity Equation
law: The productivity, P, of a group of people is: P = N x T x (.55 - .00005 x N x (N - 1) ) where N is the number of people in the group and T is the number of hours in a work period.

title: Professional's Law
law: Doctors, dentists, and lawyers are only on time for appointments when you're not.

title: Project scheduling "99" rule
law: The first 90 percent of the task takes 90 percent of the time. The last 10 percent takes the other 90 percent.

title: Proverbial Law
law: For every proverb that so confidently asserts its little bit of wisdom, there is usually an equal and opposite proverb that contradicts it.

title: Public Relations Client Turnover Law
law: The minute you sign a client is the minute you start to lose him.

title: First Rule of Public Speaking
law: Nice guys finish fast.

title: Pudder's Law
law: Anything that begins well ends badly. Anything that begins badly ends worse.

title: Puritan's Law
law: Evil is live spelled backwards.

corollary.law: If it feels good, don't do it.

title: Putney's Law
law: If the people of a democracy are allowed to do so, they will vote away the freedoms which are essential to that democracy.

title: Putt's Law
law: Technology is dominated by two types of people -- those who understand what they do not manage, and those who manage what they do not understand.

title: Q's Law
law: No matter what stage of completion one reaches in a North Sea (oil) field, the cost of the remainder of the project remains the same.

title: Rakove's Laws of Politics
laws: The amount of effort put into a campaign by a worker expands in proportion to the personal benefits that he will derive from his party's victory.
The citizen is influenced by principle in direct proportion to his distance from the political situation.

title: Ralph's Observation
law: It is a mistake to allow any mechanical object to realize that you are in a hurry.

title: Randolph's Cardinal Principle of Statecraft
law: Never needlessly disturb a thing at rest.

title: Rangnekar's Modified Rules Concerning Decisions
laws: If you must make a decision, delay it.
If you can authorize someone else to avoid a decision, do so.
If you can form a committee, have them avoid the decision.
If you can otherwise avoid a decision, avoid it immediately.

title: Rapoport's Rule of the Roller-Skate Key
law: Certain items which are crucial to a given activity will show up with uncommon regularity until the day when that activity is planned, at which point the item in question will disappear from the face of the earth.

title: Raskin's Zero Law
law: The more zeros found in the price tag for a government program, the less Congressional scrutiny it will receive.

title: Law of Raspberry Jam
law: The wider any culture is spread, the thinner it gets.

title: Rather's Rule
law: In dealing with the press do yourself a favor. Stick with one of three responses: (a) I know and I can tell you, (b) I know and I can't tell you, or (c) I don't know.

title: Rayburn's Rule
law: If you want to get along, go along.

title: Fundamental Tenet of Reform
law: Reforms come from below. No man with four aces howls for a new deal.

title: Law of Reruns
law: If you have watched a TV series only once, and you watch it again, it will be a rerun of the same episode.

title: Law of Research
law: Enough research will tend to support your theory.

title: Law of Restaurant Acoustics
law: In a restaurant with seats which are close to each other, one will always find the decibel level of the nearest conversation to be inversely proportional to the quality of the thought going into it.

title: Law of Revelation
law: The hidden flaw never remains hidden.

title: First Law of Revision
law: Information necessitating a change of design will be conveyed to the designer after -- and only after -- the plans are complete. (Often called the "Now they tell us!" Law.)

corollary.law: In simple cases, presenting one obvious right way versus one obvious wrong way, it is often wiser to choose the wrong way, so as to expedite subsequent revision.

title: Second Law of Revision
law: The more innocuous the modification appears to be, the further its influence will extend and the more plans will have to be redrawn.

title: Third Law of Revision
law: If, when completion of a design is imminent, field dimensions are finally supplied as they actually are -- instead of as they were meant to be -- it is always easier to start all over.

corollary.law: It is usually impractical to worry beforehand about interferences -- if you have none, someone will make one for you.

title: Fourth Law of Revision
law: After painstaking and careful analysis of a sample, you are always told that it is the wrong sample and doesn't apply to the problem.

title: Richard's Complementary Rules of Ownership
laws: If you keep anything long enough you can throw it away.
If you throw anything away, you will need it as soon as i is no longer accessible.

title: Richman's Inevitables of Parenthood
laws: Enough is never enough.
The sun always rises in the baby's bedroom window.
Birthday parties always end in tears.
Whenever you decide to take the kids hme, it is always five minutes earlier that they break into fights, tears, or hysteria.

title: Riddle's Constant
law: There are coexisting elements in frustration phenomena which separate expected results from achieved results.

title: Riesman's Law
law: An inexorable upward movement leads administrators to higher salaries and narrower spans of control.

title: Rigg's Hypothesis
law: Incompetence tends to increase with the level of work performed. And, naturally, the individual's staff needs will increase as his level of incompetence increases.

title: Law of Road Construction
law: After large expenditures of federal, state, and county funds; after much confusion generated by detours and road blocks; after greatly annoying the surrounding population with noise, dust, and fumes -- the previously existing traffic jam is relocated by one-half mile.

title: Robertson's Law
law: Everything happens at the same time with nothing in between.

title: The Three Laws of Robotics
laws: A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.
A robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law.
A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws.

title: Rodovic's Rule
law: In any organization, the potential is much greater for the subordinate to manage his superior than for the superior to manage his subordinate.

title: Rodriguez's Observation
law: A consultant is someone who, when hired to find out what time it is, borrows your watch to find out.

title: Corollary (Martin)
law: If you hire a consultant to read your own watch to you, you got your money's worth.

title: Roemer's Law
law: The rate of hospital admissions responds to bed availability. If we insist on installing more beds, they will tend to get filled.

title: Roger's Ratio
law: One-third of the people in the United States promote, while the other two-thirds provide.

title: Rosenbaum's Rule
law: The easiest way to find something lost around the house is to buy a replacement.

title: Rosenfield's Regret
law: The most delicate component will be dropped.

title: Rosenstock-Huessy's Law of Technology
law: All technology expands the space, contracts the time, and destroys the working group.

title: (Al) Ross's Law
law: Bare feet magnetize sharp metal objects so they always point upward from the floor -- especially in the dark.

title: (Charles) Ross's Law
law: Never characterize the importance of a statement in advance.

title: Rudin's Law
law: In a crisis that forces a choice to be made among alternative courses of action, most people will choose the worse one possible.

title: Runamok's Law
law: There are four kinds of people: those who sit quietly and do nothing, those who talk about sitting quietly and doing nothing, those who do things, and those who talk about doing things.

title: Runyon's Law
law: The race is not always to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, but that's the way to bet.

title: First Rule of Rural Mechanics
law: If it works, don't fix it.

title: Ryan's Law
law: Make three correct guesses consecutively and you will establish yourself as an expert.

title: Sadat's Reminder
law: Those who invented the law of supply and demand have no right to complain when this law works against their interest.

title: Sam's Axioms
laws: Any line, however short, is still too long.
Work is the crabgrass of life, but money is te water that keeps it green.

title: Sattinger's Law
law: It works better if you plug it in.

title: Sattler's Law
law: There are 32 points to the compass, meaning that there are 32 directions in which a spoon can squirt grapefruit; yet, the juice almost invariably flies straight into the human eye.

title: Saunders's Discovery
law: Laziness is the mother of nine inventions out of ten.

title: Sayre's Third Law of Politics
law: Academic politics is the most vicious and bitter form of politics, because the stakes are so low.

title: Schenk's First Principle of Industrial Market Economics
law: Good salesmen and good repairmen will never go hungry.

title: Schickel's TV Theorems
laws: Any dramatic series the producers want us to take seriously as a representation of contemporary reality cannot be taken seriously as a representation of anything -- except a show to be ignored by anyone capable of sitting upright in a chair and chewing gum simultaneously.
The only programs a grown-up can possibly stand are those intended for children. Or, more properly, those that cater to those pre-adolescent fantasies that most have never abandoned.

title: Schmidt's Law
law: Never eat prunes when you're hungry.

title: Schmidt's Law (probably a different Schmidt)
law: If you mess with something long enough, it'll break.

title: Schuckit's Law
law: All interference in human conduct has the potential for causing harm, no matter how innocuous the procedure may be.

title: Schultze's Law
law: If you can't measure output, then you measure input.

title: Schumpeter's Observation of Scientific and Nonscientific Theories
law: Any theory can be made to fit any facts by means of appropriate additional assumptions.

title: Old Scottish Prayer
law: O Lord, grant that we may always be right, for Thou knowest we will never change our minds.

title: Scott's First Law
law: No matter what goes wrong, it will probably look right.

title: Scott's Second Law
law: When an error has been detected and corrected, it will be found to have been correct in the first place.

corollary.law: After the correction has been found in error, it will be impossible to fit the original quantity back into the equation.

title: Screwdriver Syndrome
law: Sometimes, where a complex problem can be illuminated by many tools, one can be forgiven for applying the one he knows best.

title: Segal's Law
law: A man with one watch knows what time it is; a man with two watches is never sure.

title: Law of Selective Gravity (the Buttered Side Down Law)
law: An object will fall so as to do the most damage.

title: Corollary (Klipstein)
law: The most delicate component will be the one to drop.

title: Sells's Law
law: The first sample is always the best.

title: Laws of Serendipity
laws: In order to discover anything you must be looking for something.
If you wish to make an improved product, you must already be engagd in making an inferior one.

title: Sevareid's Law
law: The chief cause of problems is solutions.

title: Shaffer's Law
law: The effectiveness of a politician varies in inverse proportion to his commitment to principle.

title: Shalit's Law
law: The intensity of movie publicity is in inverse ratio to the quality of the movie.

title: Shanahan's Law
law: The length of a meeting rises with the square of the number of people present.

title: Sharkey's Fourth Law of Motion
law: Passengers on elevators constantly rearrange their positions as people get on and off so there is at all times an equal distance between all bodies.

title: Shaw's Principle
law: Build a system that even a fool can use, and only a fool will want to use it.

title: Shelton's Laws of Pocket Calculators
laws: Rechargeable batteries die at the most critical time of the most complex problem.
When a rechargeable battery starts to die in the middle of a complex calculation, and the user attempts to connect house current, the calculator will clear itself.
The final answer will exceed the magnitude or precision or both of the calculator.
There are not enough storage registers to solve the problem.
The user will forget mathematics in proportion to the complexity of the calculator.
Thermal paper will run out before the calculation is complete.

title: Shirley's Law
law: Most people deserve each other.

title: Short's Quotations
laws: Any great truth can -- and eventually will -- be expressed as a cliche. A cliche is a sure and certain way to dilute an idea. For instance, my grandmother used to say, "The black cat is always the last one off the fence." I have no idea what she meant, but at one time it was undoubtedly true.
Half of being smart is knowing what you're dumb at.
Malpractice makes malperfect.
Neurosis is a communicable disease.
The only winner in the War of 1812 was Tchaikovsky.

Nature abhors a hero. For one thing, he violates the law of conservation of energy. For another, how can it be the survival of the fittest when the fittest keeps putting himself in situations where he is most likely to be creamed?
A little ignorance can go a long way.
Learn to be sincere. Even if you have to fake it.
There is no such thing as an absolute truth -- that is absolutely true.
Understanding the laws of nature does not mean we are free from obeying them.
Entropy has us outnumbered.
The human race never solves any of its problems -- it only outlives them.
Hell hath no fury like a pacifist.

title: Law of Selective Gravity
law: An object will fall so as to do the most damage.

title: Sevareid's Law
law: The chief cause of problems is solutions.

title: Mother Sigafoos's Observation
law: A man should be greater than some of his parts.

title: Simmon's Law
law: The desire for racial integration increases with the square of the distance from the actual event.

title: Simon's Law
law: Everything put together sooner or later falls apart.

title: Sinner's Law of Retaliation
law: Do whatever your enemies don't want you to do.

title: Skinner's Constant (Flannegan's Finagling Factor)
law: That quantity which, when multiplied by, divided into, added to, or subtracted from the answer you got, gives you the answer you should have gotten.

title: Skole's Rule for Antique Dealers
law: Never simply say, "Sorry, we don't have what you're looking for." Always say, "Too bad, I just sold one the other day".

title: Law of Slide Presentation
law: In any slide presentation, at least one slide will be upside down or backwards, or both.

title: Smith's Principles of Bureaucratic Tinkertoys
laws: Never use one word when a dozen will suffice.
If it can be understood, it's not finished yet.
Never be the first to do anything.

title: Snafu Equations
laws: Given any problem containing n equations, there will be n+1 unknowns.
An object or bit of information most needed, will be least available.
In any human endeavor, once you have exhausted all possibilities and fail, there will be one solution, simple and obvious, highly visible to everyone else.
Badness comes in waves.

title: First Law of Socio-Economics
law: In a hierarchical system, the rate of pay for a given task increases in inverse ratio to the unpleasantness and difficulty of the task.

title: First Law of Socio-Genetics
law: Celibacy is not hereditary.

title: Woods's Refutation of the First Law of Socio-Genetics
law: On the contrary, if you never procreate, neither will your kids.

title: Sociology's Iron Law of Oligarchy
law: In every organized activity, no matter the sphere, a small number will become the oligarchical leaders and the others will follow.

title: Sodd's First Law
law: When a person attempts a task, he or she will be thwarted in that task by the unconscious intervention of some other presence (animate or inanimate). Nevertheless, some tasks are completed, since the intervening presence is itself attempting a task and is, of course, subject to interference.

title: Sodd's Second Law
law: Sooner or later, the worst possible set of circumstances is bound to occur.

corollary.law: Any system must be designed to withstand the worst possible set of circumstances.

title: Sodd's Other Law
law: The degree of failure is in direct proportion to the effort expended and to the need for success.

title: Grandma Soderquist's Conclusion
law: A chicken doesn't stop scratching just because the worms are scarce.

title: Spare Parts Principle
law: The accessibility, during recovery of small parts which fall from the work bench, varies directly with the size of the part and inversely with its importance to the completion of the work underway.

title: Spark's Ten Rules for the Project Manager
laws: Strive to look tremendously important.
Attempt to be seen with important people.
Speak with authority; however, only expound on the obvious and proven facts.
Don't engage in arguments, but if cornered, ask an irrelevant question and lean back with a satisfied grin while your opponent tries to figure out what's going on -- then quickly change the subject.
Listen intently while others are arguing the problem. Pounce on a trite statement and bury them with it.
If a subordinate asks you a pertinent question, look at him as if he had lost his senses. When he looks down, paraphrase the question back at him.
Obtain a brilliant assignment, but keep out of sight and out of the limelight.
Walk at a fast pace when out of the office -- this keeps questions from subordinates and superiors at a minimum.
Always keep the office door closed. This puts visitors on the defensive and also makes it look as if you are always in an important conference.
Give all orders verbally. Never write anything down that might go into a "Pearl Harbor File."

title: Specht's Meta-Law
law: Under any conditions, anywhere, whatever you are doing, there is some ordinance under which you can be booked.

title: Sprinkle's Law
law: Things always fall at right angles.

title: Steele's Plagiarism of Somebody's Philosophy
law: Everyone should believe in something -- I believe I'll have another drink.

title: Steinbeck's Law
law: When you need towns, they are very far apart.

title: Stephens's Soliloquy
law: Finality is death. Perfection is finality. Nothing is perfect. There are lumps in it.

title: Stewart's Law of Retroaction
law: It is easier to get forgiveness than permission.

title: Stockbroker's Declaration
law: The market will rally from this or lower levels.

title: Stock Market Axiom
law: The public is always wrong.

title: Stock's Observation
law: You no sooner get your head above water than someone pulls your flippers off.

title: Sturgeon's Law
law: Ninety percent of everything is crud.

title: Sueker's Note
law: If you need n items of anything, you will have n - 1 in stock.

title: Suhor's Law
law: A little ambiguity never hurt anyone.

title: Law of Superiority
law: The first example of superior principle is always inferior to the developed example of inferior principle.

title: Law of Superstition
law: It's bad luck to be superstititious.

title: Survival Formula for Public Office
laws: Exploit the inevitable (which means, take credit for anything good which happens whether you had anything to do with it or not).
Don't disturb the perimeter (meaning don't stir up a mess unless you can be sure of the result).
Stay in with the Outs (the Ins will make so many mistakes, you can't afford to alienate the Outs).
Don't permit yourself to get between a dog and a lamppost.

title: Sutton's Law
law: Go where the money is.

title: Swipple's Rule of Order
law: He who shouts loudest has the floor.

title: Taxi Principle
law: Find out the cost before you get in.

title: Terman's Law
law: There is no direct relationship between the quality of an educational program and its cost.

title: Terman's Law of Innovation
law: If you want a track team to win the high jump you find one person who can jump seven feet, not seven people who can jump one foot.

title: Thinking Man's Tautology
law: If you think you're wrong, you're wrong.

corollary.law: If you think you're wrong, you're right.

title: Thoreau's Law
law: If you see a man approaching with the obvious intent of doing you good, run for your life.

title: Thoreau's Rule
law: Any fool can make a rule, and every fool will mind it.

title: Thurber's Conclusion
law: There is no safety in numbers, or in anything else.

title: Thwartz's Theorem of Low Profile
law: Negative expectation thwarts realization, and self-congratulation guarantees disaster. (Or, simply put: If you think of it, it won't happen quite that way.)

title: Tipper's Law
law: Those who expect the biggest tips provide the worst service.

title: Titanic Coincidence
law: Most accidents in well-designed systems involve two or more events of low probability occurring in the worst possible combination.

title: Torquemada's Law
law: When you are sure you're right, you have a moral duty to impose your will upon anyone who disagrees with you.

title: Transcription Square Law
law: The number of errors made is equal to the sum of the squares employed.

title: Travel Axiom
law: He travels fastest who travels alone... but he hasn't anything to do when he gets there.

title: First Law of Travel
law: No matter how many rooms there are in the motel, the fellow who starts up his car at five o'clock in the morning is always parked under your window.

title: Trischmann's Paradox (Axiom of the Pipe)
law: A pipe gives a wise man time to think and a fool something to stick in his mouth.

title: Law of Triviality
law: The time spent on any item of the agenda will be in inverse proportion to the sum involved.

title: Troutman's Laws of Computer Programming
laws: Any running program is obsolete.
Any planned program costs more and takes longer.
Any useful program will have to be changed.
Any useless program will have to be documented.
The size of a program expands to fill all available memory.
The value of a program is inversely proportional to the weight of its output.
The complexity of a program grows until it exceeds the capability of its maintainers.
Any system that relies on computer reliability is unreliable.
Any system that relies on human reliability is unreliable.
Make it possible for programmers to write programs in English, and you will find that programmers cannot write in English.
Profanity is the one language all programmers know best.

title: Truman's Law
law: If you cannot convince them, confuse them.

title: Tuccille's First Law of Reality
law: Industry always moves in to fill an economic vacuum.

title: Turnauckas's Observation
law: To err is human; to really foul things up takes a computer.

title: Turner's Law
law: Nearly all prophecies made in public are wrong.

title: Twain's Rule
law: Only kings, editors, and people with tapeworm have the right to use the editorial "we".

title: Tylk's Law
law: Assumption is the mother of all foul-ups.

title: Ubell's Law of Press Luncheons
law: At any public relations luncheon, the quality of the food is inversely related to the quality of the information.

title: Uhlmann's Razor
law: When stupidity is a sufficient explanation, there is no need to have recourse to any other.

corollary.title: Law of Historical Causation
corollary.law: It seemed like the thing to do at the time.

title: The Ultimate Law
law: All general statements are false.

title: The Ultimate Principle
law: By definition, when you are investigating the unknown, you do not know what you will find.

title: Umbrella Law
law: You will need three umbrellas: one to leave at the office, one to leave at home, and one to leave on the train.

title: The Unapplicable Law
law: Washing your car to make it rain doesn't work.

title: Universal Field Theory of Perversity (Mule's Law)
law: The probability of an event's occurring varies directly with the perversity of the inanimate object involved and inversely with the product of its desirability and the effort expended to produce it.

title: Unnamed Law
law: If it happens, it must be possible.

title: The Unspeakable Law
law: As soon as you mention something, if it's good, it goes away; if it's bad, it happens.

title: Vail's Axiom
law: In any human enterprise, work seeks the lowest hierarchical level.

title: Vance's Rule of 2 1/2
law: Any military project will take twice as long as planned, cost twice as much, and produce only half of what is wanted.

title: Lucy Van Pelt's Observation
law: There must be one day above all others in each life that is the happiest.

corollary.law: What if you've already had it?

title: Vique's Law
law: A man without religion is like a fish without a bicycle.

title: Von Braun's Law of Gravity
law: We can lick gravity, but sometimes the paperwork is overwhelming.

title: Vonnegut's Corollary
law: Beauty may be only skin deep, but ugliness goes right to the core.

title: Waddell's Law of Equipment Failure
law: A component's degree of reliability is directly proportional to its ease of accessibility (i.e., the harder it is to get to, the more often it breaks down).

title: Waffle's Law
law: A professor's enthusiasm for teaching the introductory course varies inversely with the likelihood of his having to do it.

title: Wain's Conclusion
law: The only people making money these days are the ones who sell computer paper.

title: Waldo's Observation
law: One man's red tape is another man's system.

title: Walinsky's Law
law: The intelligence of any discussion diminishes with the square of the number of participants.

title: Walinsky's First Law of Political Campaigns
law: If there are twelve clowns in a ring, you can jump in the middle and start reciting Shakespeare, but to the audience, you'll just be the thirteenth clown.

title: Walker's Law
law: Associate with well-mannered persons and your manners will improve. Run with decent folk and your own decent instincts will be strengthened. Keep the company of bums and you will become a bum. Hang around with rich people and you will end by picking up the check and dying broke.

title: Wallace's Observation
law: Everything is in a state of utter dishevelment.

title: Walters's Law of Management
law: If you're already in a hole, there's no use to continue digging.

title: Washington's Law
law: Space expands to house the people to perform the work that Congress creates.

title: Watson's Law
law: The reliability of machinery is inversely proportional to the number and significance of any persons watching it.

title: Rule of the Way Out
law: Always leave room to add an explanation if it doesn't work out.

title: Weaver's Law
law: When several reporters share a cab on an assignment, the reporter in the front seat pays for all.

title: Corollary (O'Doyle)
law: No matter how many reporters share a cab, and no matter who pays, each puts the full fare on his own expense account.

title: Corollary (Germond)
law: When a group of newsmen go out to dinner together, the bill is to be divided evenly among them, regardless of what eac one eats and drinks.

title: Weber-Fechner Law
law: The least change in stimulus necessary to produce a perceptible change in response is proportional to the stimulus already existing.

title: Weidner's Queries
laws: The tide comes in and the tide goes out, and what have you got?
They say an elephant never forgets, but what's he got to remember?

title: Weiler's Law
law: Nothing is impossible for the man who doesn't have to do it himself.

title: Weinberg's Law
law: If builders built buildings the way programmers wrote programs, then the first woodpecker that came along would destroy civilization.

corollary.law: An expert is a person who avoids the small errors while sweeping on to the grand fallacy.

title: Weisman's Law of Examinations
law: If you're confident after you've just finished an exam, it's because you don't know enough to know better.

title: Wells's Law
law: A parade should have bands or horses, not both.

title: Westheimer's Rule
law: To estimate the time it takes to do a task: estimate the time you think it should take, multiply by 2, and change the unit of measure to the next highest unit. Thus we allocate 2 days for a one hour task.

title: Whispered Rule
law: People will believe anything if you whisper it.

title: White Flag Principle
law: A military disaster may produce a better postwar situation than victory.

title: White's Chappaquiddick Theorem
law: The sooner and in more detail you announce bad news, the better.

title: White's Observations of Committee Operation
laws: People very rarely think in groups; they talk together, they exchange information, they adjudicate, they make compromises. But they do not think; they do not create.
A really new idea affronts current agreement.

A meeting cannot be productive unless certain remises are so shared that they do not need to be discussed, and the argument can be confined to areas of disagreement. But while this kind of consensus makes a group more effective in its legitimate functions, it does not make the group a creative vehicle -- it would not be a new idea if it didn't -- and the group, impelled as it is to agree, is instinctively hostile to that which is divisive.

title: White's Statement
law: Don't lose heart... Owen's Comment on White's Statement:... they might want to cut it out... Byrd's Addition to Owen's Comment on White's Statement:... and they want to avoid a lengthy search.

title: Whole Picture Principle
law: Research scientists are so wrapped up in their own narrow endeavors that they cannot possibly see the whole picture of anything, including their own research.

corollary.law: The Director of Research should know as little as possible about the specific subject of research he is administering.

title: Wicker's Law
law: Government expands to absorb revenue, and then some.

title: Wilcox's Law
law: A pat on the back is only a few centimeters from a kick in the pants.

title: Williams and Holland's Law
law: If enough data is collected, anything may be proven by statistical methods.

title: Will's Rule of Informed Citizenship
law: If you want to understand your government, don't begin by reading the Constitution. (It conveys precious little of the flavor of today's statecraft.) Instead read selected portions of the Washington telephone directory containing listings for all the organizations with titles beginning with the word "National".

title: Flip Wilson's Law
law: You can't expect to hit the jackpot if you don't put a few nickles in the machine.

title: Wilson's Law of Demographics
law: The public is not made up of people who get their names in the newspapers.

title: Wingo's Axiom
law: All Finagle Laws may be bypassed by learning the simple art of doing without thinking.

title: First Law of Wing-Walking
law: Never leave hold of what you've got until you've got hold of something else.

title: Witten's Law
law: Whenever you cut your fingernails, you will find a need for them an hour later.

title: Wober's SNIDE Rule (Satisfied Needs Incite Demand Excesses)
law: Ideal goals grow faster than the means of attaining new goals allow.

title: Wolf's Law (An Optimistic View of a Pessimistic World)
law: It isn't that things will necessarily go wrong (Murphy's Law), but rather that they will take so much more time and effort than you think if they are not to go wrong.

title: Wolf's Law of Decision-Making
law: Major actions are rarely decided by more than four people. If you think a larger meeting you're attending is really "hammering out" a decision, you're probably wrong. Either the decision was agreed to by a smaller group before the meeting began, or the outcome of the larger meeting will be modified later when three or four people get together.

title: Wolf's Law of History Lessons
law: Those who don't study the past will repeat its errors. Those who do study it will find other ways to err.

title: Wolf's Law of Management
law: The tasks to do immediately are the minor ones; otherwise, you'll forget them. The major ones are often better to defer. They usually need more time for reflection. Besides, if you forget them, they'll remind you.

title: Wolf's Law of Meetings
law: The only important result of a meeting is agreement about next steps.

title: Wolf's Law of Planning
law: A good place to start from is where you are.

title: Wolf's Law of Tactics
law: If you can't beat them, have them join you.

title: Woltman's Law
law: Never program and drink beer at the same time.

title: Woman's Equation
law: Whatever women do, they must do twice as well as men to be thought half as good. Luckily, this is not difficult.

title: Wood's Law
law: The more unworkable the urban plan, the greater the probability of implementation.

title: Woods's Incomplete Maxims
laws: All's well that ends.
A penny saved is a penny.
Don't leave things unfinishe

title: Woods's Laws of Procrastination
laws: Never put off till tomorrow what you can do the day after tomorrow.
Procrastinate today! (Tomorrow may be too late.)
NOW is the time to do things later!
If at first you don't succeed, why try again?

title: Woodward's Law
law: A theory is better than an explanation.

title: Worker's Dilemma Law (Management's Put-Down Law)
laws: No matter how much you do, you'll never do enough.
What you don't do is always more important than whatyou do do.

title: Wynne's Law
law: Negative slack tends to increase.

title: Wyszkowski's Theorem
law: Regardless of the units used by either the supplier or the customer, the manufacturer shall use his own arbitrary units convertible to those of either the supplier or the customer only by means of weird and unnatural conversion factors.

title: Wyszowski's First Law
law: No experiment is reproducible.

title: Wyszkowski's Second Law
law: Anything can be made to work if you fiddle with it long enough.

title: Yapp's Basic Fact
law: If a thing cannot be fitted into something smaller than itself, some dope will do it.

title: Yolen's Guide for Self-Praise
law: Proclaim yourself "World Champ" of something -- tiddly-winks, rope- jumping, whatever -- send this notice to newspapers, radio, TV, and wait for challengers to confront you. Avoid challenges as long as possible, but continue to send news of your achievements to all media. Also, develop a newsletter and letterhead for communications.

title: Young's Handy Guide to the Modern Sciences
law: If it is green or it wiggles -- it is Biology. If it stinks -- it is Chemistry. If it doesn't work -- it is Physics.

title: Young's Law
law: All great discoveries are made by mistake.

corollary.law: The greater the funding, the longer it takes to make the mistake.

title: Zellar's Law
law: Every newspaper, no matter how tight the news hole, has room for a story on another newspaper increasing its newsstand price.

title: Zimmerman's Law
law: Regardless of whether a mission expands or contracts, administrative overhead continues to grow at a steady rate.

title: Zimmerman's Law of Complaints
law: Nobody notices when things go right.

title: Zusmann's Rule
law: A successful symposium depends on the ratio of meeting to eating.

title: Zymurgy's First Law of Evolving System Dynamics
law: Once you open a can of worms, the only way to recan them is to use a larger can. (Old worms never die, they just worm their way into larger cans.)

title: Zymurgy's Seventh Exception to Murphy's Laws
law: When it rains, it pours.

title: Zymurgy's Law of Volunteer Labour
law: People are always available for work in the past tense.
